description.summary: Provisional estimates of UK manufacturers‘ sales of individual products covered by the ProdCom survey.
description.title: UK manufacturers‘ sales by product
description.metaDescription: Provisional estimates of UK manufacturers' sales of individual products covered by the ProdCom survey.
description.headline1: The value of UK manufacturers’ product sales was £380.7 billion in 2017, a 4.1% increase on the 2016 final revised total of £365.7 billion.
description.headline2: Manufacturing of food products experienced the largest increase in sales between 2016 and 2017, at £4.2 billion (6.4%), to 69.9 billion.
description.headline3: Increases in manufacturers’ sales were also reported within the manufacture of motor vehicles division (£2.6 billion or 4.8%), manufacture of other transport equipment (£2.6 billion or 9.9%) and manufacture of machinery and equipment not elsewhere classified (£2.2 billion or 9.1%).

description.summary: A first estimate of retail sales in volume and value terms, seasonally and non-seasonally adjusted.
description.title: Retail sales, Great Britain
description.metaDescription: A first estimate of retail sales in volume and value terms, seasonally and non-seasonally adjusted.
description.headline1: In the three months to October 2018, the quantity bought in retail sales increased by 0.4% when compared with the previous three months; a slowdown to growth when compared with the strong summer sales, which reached a high of 2.3% in the three months to July.
description.headline2: In October 2018, the quantity bought fell by 0.5% when compared with September 2018, with a strong decline of 3.0% in household goods stores following a particularly strong August and September.
description.headline3: When compared with the previous year, the quantity bought in October 2018 increased by 2.2%, with growth across all sectors except fuel, which fell by 1.8%.

description.summary: An experimental price index tracking the prices paid for renting property from private landlords in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
description.title: Index of Private Housing Rental Prices, UK
description.metaDescription: An experimental price index tracking the prices paid for renting property from private landlords in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.
description.headline1: Private rental prices paid by tenants in the UK rose by 0.9% in the 12 months to October 2018, unchanged from the 12 months to September 2018.
description.headline2: In England, private rental prices grew by 0.9%, Wales experienced growth of 0.7%, while in Scotland private rental prices increased by 0.6% in the 12 months to October 2018.
description.headline3: London private rental prices fell by 0.2% in the 12 months to October 2018; unchanged from the 12 months to September 2018.

description.summary: Monthly house price inflation in the UK, calculated using data from HM Land Registry, Registers of Scotland and Land and Property Services Northern Ireland.
description.title: UK House Price Index
description.metaDescription: Monthly house price inflation in the UK, calculated using data from HM Land Registry, Registers of Scotland and Land and Property Services Northern Ireland.

description.summary: Price indices, percentage changes and weights for the different measures of consumer price inflation.
description.title: Consumer price inflation, UK
description.metaDescription: Price indices, percentage changes and weights for the different measures of consumer price inflation.
description.headline1: The Consumer Prices Index including owner occupiers’ housing costs (CPIH) 12-month inflation rate was 2.2% in October 2018, unchanged from September 2018.
description.headline2: The large downward contributions to the change in the 12-month rate from food and non-alcoholic beverages, clothing and footwear, and some transport elements were offset by upward contributions from rising petrol, diesel and domestic gas prices.

contact.name: Andy King
contact.telephone: Consumer Price Inflation Enquiries: +44 (0)1633 456900. Consumer Price Inflation recorded message (available after 9.45am on release day): + 44 (0)800 0113703

description.headline3: Other smaller upward contributions came from items in the miscellaneous goods and services, recreation and culture, and communication sectors.

description.summary: A summary of the construction output price indices (OPIs) for Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2018. Data in this release are experimental statistics.
description.title: Construction output price indices (OPIs), UK
description.metaDescription: Quarterly construction output price indices (OPIs) used in the production of chained volume measures (CVMs) for output in the construction industry.
description.headline1: The Construction Output Price Index (OPI) for all construction rose 2.7% in the year to September 2018, down from 2.8% in August 2018.
description.headline2: The OPI for all new work increased by 3.1% in the year to September 2018, down from 3.3% in August 2018; housing provided the largest contribution to the annual rate.
description.headline3: The OPI for all repair and maintenance increased 1.7% in the year to September 2018, unchanged from August 2018; the housing repair and maintenance sector increased by 1.9% over the 12-month period, providing the largest contribution to the annual rate.

description.summary: Changes in the prices of goods bought and sold by UK manufacturers including price indices of materials and fuels purchased (input prices) and factory gate prices (output prices).
description.title: Producer price inflation, UK
description.metaDescription: Input and output index series. Contains producer price indices of materials and fuels purchased and output of manufacturing industry by broad sector.
description.headline1: The headline rate of output inflation for goods leaving the factory gate was 3.3% on the year to October 2018, up from 3.1% in September 2018.
description.headline2: The growth rate of prices for materials and fuels used in the manufacturing process slowed to 10.0% on the year to October 2018, from 10.5% in September 2018.
description.headline3: All product groups provided upward contributions to output and input annual inflation, for the second consecutive month.

description.summary: Regional, local authority and Parliamentary constituency breakdowns of changes in UK employment, unemployment, economic inactivity and other employment-related statistics.
description.title: Regional labour market statistics in the UK
description.metaDescription: Regional, local authority and Parliamentary constituency breakdowns of changes in UK employment and other employment-related statistics.
description.headline1: For the three months ending September 2018, the highest employment rate estimate in the UK was in the South West (78.9%) and the lowest was in Northern Ireland (68.5%).
description.headline2: For the three months ending September 2018, the highest unemployment rate estimates in the UK were in Yorkshire and The Humber and the North East (both 5.0%) and the lowest was in the South West (2.9%).
description.headline3: For the three months ending September 2018, the highest economic inactivity rate estimate in the UK was in Northern Ireland (28.5%) and the lowest was in the South West (18.7%).

description.summary: Estimates of employment, unemployment, economic inactivity and other employment-related statistics for the UK.
description.title: UK labour market
description.metaDescription: Estimates of employment, unemployment, economic inactivity and other employment-related statistics for the UK.
description.headline1: Estimates from the Labour Force Survey show that, between April to June 2018 and July to September 2018, the number of people in work and the number of unemployed people both increased but the number of people aged from 16 to 64 years not working and not seeking nor available to work (economically inactive) was little changed.
description.headline2: There were 32.41 million people in work, 23,000 more compared with April to June 2018 and 350,000 more than for a year earlier.
description.headline3: The employment rate (the proportion of people aged from 16 to 64 years who were in work) was 75.5%, little changed compared with April to June 2018 but higher than for a year earlier (75.0%).

description.summary: Gross domestic product (GDP)  measures the value of goods and services produced in the UK. It estimates the size of and growth in the economy.
description.title: GDP monthly estimate, UK
description.metaDescription: Gross domestic product (GDP)  measures the value of goods and services produced in the UK. It estimates the size of and growth in the economy.
description.headline1: UK gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 0.6% in Quarter 3 2018
description.headline2: Quarterly GDP growth was driven mainly by the services sector, although the construction sector also had a notable positive contribution
description.headline3: Three-month growth remained strong after a weaker start to the year

description.summary: Short-term measures of output by the construction industry in Great Britain and contracts awarded for new construction work in the UK.
description.title: Construction output in Great Britain
description.metaDescription: Short-term measures of output by the construction industry in Great Britain and contracts awarded for new construction work in the UK.
description.headline1: Construction output continued to recover following a relatively weak start to the year, increasing by 2.1% in Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2018; this follows a fall of 1.6% in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018 and an increase of 0.8% in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018.
description.headline2: Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2018 was driven by all new work which increased by 2.8%, and repair and maintenance which increased by 1.0%.
description.headline3: Construction output increased by 1.7% between August and September 2018, this was driven by an increase in all new work which increased by 2.8%; this was partly offset by a fall of 0.3% in repair and maintenance.

description.summary: Movements in the volume of production for the UK production industries: manufacturing, mining and quarrying, energy supply, and water and waste management. Figures are seasonally adjusted.
description.title: Index of Production, UK
description.metaDescription: Movements in the volume of production for the UK production industries, including manufacturing. Figures are seasonally adjusted.
description.headline1: The rise of 0.8% in total production output for Quarter 3 (July to Sep) 2018, compared with Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018, is due primarily to a rise of 0.6% in manufacturing, supported by upward contributions from the other sectors.
description.headline2: The quarterly increase in manufacturing output, reverses the fall in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018, due primarily to growth from transport equipment (2.3%), and basic metals and metal products (1.9%).
description.headline3: In September 2018, total production output was estimated to have remained flat at 0.0%, compared with August 2018, due to a 0.2% rise in manufacturing being offset by downward contributions from the other main sectors.

description.summary: Monthly movements in output for the services industries.
description.title: Index of Services, UK
description.metaDescription: Monthly movements in output for the services industries.
description.headline1: Services output increased by 0.4% in Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2018 compared with Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018; following growth of 0.6% between Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018 and Quarter 2 2018.
description.headline2: The information and communication sector made the largest contribution to the quarter-on-quarter growth, contributing 0.16 percentage points.
description.headline3: The Index of Services fell by 0.1% between August 2018 and September 2018.

description.summary: First quarterly estimate of gross domestic product (GDP), containing current and constant price data on the value of goods and services to indicate the economic performance of the UK.
description.title: GDP first quarterly estimate, UK
description.metaDescription: First quarterly estimate of gross domestic product (GDP), containing current and constant price data on the value of goods and services to indicate the economic performance of the UK.
description.headline1: UK gross domestic product (GDP) in volume terms was estimated to have increased by 0.6% between Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018 and Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2018.
description.headline2: All four sectors of output contributed positively to growth in Quarter 3 2018, with the largest contribution from the services industries at 0.3 percentage points.
description.headline3: Household spending grew by 0.5% while business investment fell by 1.2% between Quarter 2 and Quarter 3 2018.

description.summary: Total value of UK exports and imports of goods and services by current price, chained volume measures and implied deflators.
description.title: UK trade
description.metaDescription: Total value of UK exports and imports of goods and services by current price, chained volume measures and implied deflators.
description.headline1: The total trade deficit (goods and services) narrowed £3.2 billion to £2.9 billion in the three months to September 2018, due mainly to an improving goods balance.
description.headline2: Goods exports increased £5.0 billion compared with a £2.1 billion rise in goods imports, resulting in the goods deficit narrowing £2.9 billion to £31.9 billion in the three months to September 2018.
description.headline3: Cars had the single-largest impact on the goods balance due to a combined £1.0 billion rise in non-EU exports and £1.7 billion fall in EU imports in the three months to September 2018.

description.summary: Size and growth within the UK non-financial sectors as measured by the Annual Business Survey.
description.title: Annual Business Survey, UK non-financial business economy
description.metaDescription: Size and growth within the UK non-financial sectors as measured by the Annual Business Survey. A key resource for business structure and performance.
description.headline1: In 2017, the approximate gross value added at basic prices (aGVA) of the UK non-financial business economy was estimated to be £1,259.9 billion; this was an increase of 5.6% (£66.7 billion) compared with 2016.
description.headline2: The estimate of aGVA represents the income (turnover) of UK businesses, less the cost of goods and services consumed in the production process (purchases); all four of the main sectors of the non-financial business economy (production, construction, distribution and non-financial services) continued to show growth in 2017.
description.headline3: The non-financial services sector, which accounted for over half (56.7%) of total aGVA in 2017, saw an increase of 6.8% (£45.3 billion); professional, scientific and technical services provided the highest levels of aGVA within this sector, increasing by £12.0 billion in 2017.

description.summary: Annual UK estimates of the number of children living in households where all adults have not worked for at least 12 months.
description.title: Children living in long-term workless households in the UK
description.metaDescription: Annual UK estimates of the number of children living in households where all adults have not worked for at least 12 months.
description.headline1: In 2017, 1.1 million children (8.6%) lived in long-term workless households.
description.headline2: Of all children in workless households, 79% lived in long-term workless households.
description.headline3: The South East and the South West had the lowest percentage of children in long-term workless households.

description.summary: Important measures of employee earnings, using data from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE). Figures are presented mainly for full-time employees, although some detail for part-time workers is also included.
description.title: Employee earnings in the UK
description.metaDescription: Important measures of employee earnings, using data from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE). Figures are presented mainly for full-time employees, although some detail for part-time workers is also included.
description.headline1: Median full-time weekly earnings increased 3.5% compared with 2017, to £569.
description.headline2: Earnings growth was highest in 2018 in the lowest-paid occupations.
description.headline3: Increased polarisation of pay between the highest earning regions and the lowest.

description.summary: The distribution of earnings of high- and low-paid jobs, earnings by selected percentiles and jobs paid below the National Minimum Wage. Compiled from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE).
description.title: Low and high pay in the UK
description.metaDescription: The distribution of earnings of high- and low-paid jobs, earnings by selected percentiles and jobs paid below the National Minimum Wage. Compiled from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE).

description.summary: National population estimates broken down into small geographical areas (Super Output Areas, health geographies, wards, Parliamentary constituencies and National Parks).
description.title: Small area population estimates, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: National population estimates broken down into small geographical areas.
description.headline1: There continues to be wide variations in the age structure of the population across England and Wales, with coastal and rural areas tending to have the older populations than cities and urban areas.
description.headline2: In mid-2017, the Lower layer Super Output Area (LSOA) with the highest median age was Eastbourne 012B at 70.8 years, whereas Salford 016E had the lowest median age at 14.7 years; across all of England and Wales the median age was 39.9 years.
description.headline3: The proportion of people aged over 65 years living in areas served by different clinical commissioning groups (CCGs) in England ranged from 6.2% in Tower Hamlets to 29.6% in NHS North Norfolk (across England 18.0% of the population are aged 65 years or over).

description.summary: Differences in pay between women and men by age, region, full-time and part-time, and occupation as compiled from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE). The gender pay gap is the percentage difference between men's and women’s median hourly earnings, across all jobs in the UK; it is not a measure of the difference in pay between men and women for doing the same job.
description.title: Gender pay gap in the UK
description.metaDescription: Differences in pay between women and men by age, region, full-time and part-time, and occupation as compiled from the Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings (ASHE).

description.summary: Trade in services data, including breakdown of exports and imports by country and geographical region, EU and non-EU.
description.title: UK trade in services by partner country experimental data
description.metaDescription: Trade in services data, including breakdown of exports and imports by country and geographical region, EU and non-EU.
description.headline1: This release covers all the UK economy’s trade in services, presenting UK trade in services by 67 countries and 31 service types; this supersedes our previous quarterly release which only used data from the International Trade in Services Survey.
description.headline2: The value of UK exports and imports of services increased in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018.
description.headline3: The European Union (EU) remained the UK’s largest trading partner for both exports and imports of services in Quarter 2 2018, while the US was the largest trading partner when considering individual countries.

description.summary: Registered deaths by age, sex, selected underlying causes of death and the leading causes of death for both males and females.
description.title: Deaths registered in England and Wales (series DR)
description.metaDescription: Registered deaths by age, sex, selected underlying causes of death and the leading causes of death for both males and females.
description.headline1: Deaths due to dementia and Alzheimer disease increased again in 2017 and it remained the leading cause of death in England and Wales, accounting for 12.7% of all deaths registered.
description.headline2: Ischaemic heart diseases remained the second leading cause of death in 2017, accounting for 10.9% of deaths registered, a smaller proportion than the previous year.
description.headline3: Chronic lower respiratory diseases were the third leading cause of death, overtaking cerebrovascular disease.

description.summary: How the relationship between UK public sector monthly income and expenditure leads to changes in deficit and debt.
description.title: Public sector finances, UK
description.metaDescription: How the relationship between UK public sector monthly income and expenditure leads to changes in deficit and debt.
description.headline1: Borrowing (Public sector net borrowing excluding public sector banks) in September 2018 was £4.1 billion, £0.8 billion less than in September 2017; this was the lowest September borrowing for 11 years (since 2007).
description.headline2: Borrowing in the current financial year-to-date (YTD) was £19.9 billion: £10.7 billion less than in the same period in 2017; the lowest year-to-date for 16 years (since 2002).
description.headline3: Borrowing in the financial year ending (FYE) March 2018 was £39.8 billion: £5.7 billion less than in FYE March 2017; the lowest financial year for 11 years (since FYE 2007).

description.summary: The net rate of return on capital employed for UK private non-financial corporations related to their UK operations.
description.title: Profitability of UK companies
description.metaDescription: Net rate of return on capital employed for UK private non-financial corporations related to their UK operations.
description.headline1: Private non-financial corporations’ (PNFCs’) net rate of return rose to 12.7% in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018, from a revised estimate of 12.5% in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018.
description.headline2: The net rate of return for manufacturing companies fell for the second consecutive quarter, standing at 15.1% for Quarter 2 2018, down 0.6 percentage points from the Quarter 4 (Oct to Dec) 2017 position of 15.7%.
description.headline3: Services companies’ net rate of return recovered moderately in Quarter 2 2018 to 17.2%, from a revised estimate of 16.6% in Quarter 1 2018.

description.summary: Quarterly estimates of UK government deficit and debt, given to the European Commission under the excessive deficit procedure protocol, as part of the Maastricht Treaty.
description.title: UK government debt and deficit
description.metaDescription: Quarterly estimates of UK government deficit and debt, given to the European Commission under the excessive deficit procedure protocol, as part of the Maastricht Treaty.
description.headline1: General government gross debt was £1,763.8 billion at the end of the financial year ending March 2018, equivalent to 85.6% of gross domestic product (GDP), 25.6 percentage points above the reference value of 60% set out in the Protocol on the Excessive Deficit Procedure.
description.headline2: General government gross debt first exceeded the 60% Maastricht reference value at the financial year ending March 2010, when it was 69.6% of GDP.
description.headline3: General government deficit (or net borrowing) was £41.0 billion in the financial year ending March 2018, a decrease of £5.9 billion compared with the financial year ending March 2017; this is equivalent to 2.0% of GDP, 1.0 percentage point below the reference value of 3.0% set out in the Protocol on the Excessive Deficit Procedure.

description.summary: Crime against households and adults, also including data on crime experienced by children, and crimes against businesses and society.
description.title: Crime in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Crime against households and adults, also including data on crime experienced by children, and crimes against businesses and society.

description.summary: Quarterly estimates monitoring the changes in prices charged for services provided to UK-based customers for a range of industries.
description.title: Services producer price inflation, UK
description.metaDescription: Quarterly estimates monitoring the changes in prices charged for services provided to UK-based customers for a range of industries.
description.headline1: The annual rate of growth for the Services Producer Price Index (SPPI) was 1.8% in Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2018, up from 1.6% in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018.
description.headline2: The price of services sold by UK companies rose 0.5% in Quarter 3 2018, up from 0.4% in Quarter 2 2018.
description.headline3: Transportation and storage services; and professional, scientific and technical activities provided the largest upward contributions to both the annual and quarterly rate.

description.summary: Visits to the UK by overseas residents, visits abroad by UK residents and spending by travellers, using provisional passenger traffic data.
description.edition: April, May and June 2018 provisional results
description.title: Overseas travel and tourism
description.metaDescription: Monthly estimates of completed international visits to and from the UK and earnings and expenditure associated with these visits.
description.headline1: There were 3.3 million visits to the UK by overseas residents in April 2018 (11% fewer than in April 2017), 3.5 million visits in May 2018 (3% fewer than in May 2017) and 3.2 million visits in June 2018 (9% fewer than in June 2017).
description.headline2: There were 3.3 million visits to the UK by overseas residents in April 2018 (11% fewer than in April 2017), 3.5 million visits in May 2018 (3% fewer than in May 2017) and 3.2 million visits in June 2018 (9% fewer than in June 2017).
description.headline3: There were 3.3 million visits to the UK by overseas residents in April 2018 (11% fewer than in April 2017), 3.5 million visits in May 2018 (3% fewer than in May 2017) and 3.2 million visits in June 2018 (9% fewer than in June 2017).

description.summary: Presents a rounded and comprehensive basis for assessing changes in economic well-being through indicators that adjust or supplement more traditional measures such as gross domestic product (GDP).
description.title: Economic well-being, UK
description.metaDescription: Presents a rounded and comprehensive basis for assessing changes in economic well-being through indicators that adjust or supplement more traditional measures such as gross domestic product (GDP).
description.headline1: Of the four main measures of economic well-being, gross domestic product per head, real household disposable income per head and real household spending per head rose in Quarter 2 (April to June) 2018 by 0.2%, 0.3% and 0.2% respectively, while real net national disposable income per head decreased by 0.2%.
description.headline2: The quarterly decrease in net national disposable income per head was due to larger payments of investment income out of the country, increasing by £2.9 billion in Quarter 2 2018.
description.headline3: Real household disposable income per head dropped by 0.1% compared with the same quarter a year ago, driven mainly by an increase in taxes, equating to a £37.20 increase in taxes per person.

description.summary: Output per hour, output per job and output per worker for the whole economy and a range of industries. Includes estimates of unit labour costs.
description.title: Labour productivity, UK
description.metaDescription: Output per hour, per job and per worker for the UK economy and a range of industries including unit labour costs.

description.summary: UK businesses broken down by legal status, industry, region, employment and turnover size bands.
description.title: UK business; activity, size and location
description.metaDescription: Business enterprises analysed by legal form, industry, region and employment size band.
description.headline1: The number of Value Added Tax (VAT) and/or Pay As You Earn (PAYE) businesses in the UK as of March 2018, remained at 2.67 million, broadly unchanged from March 2017.
description.headline2: The number of companies and public corporations has continued to rise and represents 71.4% of total UK businesses, which has offset a gradual fall in sole proprietors and partnerships.
description.headline3: The largest industry group is professional, scientific and technical, making up 17.5% of all registered businesses in the UK.

description.summary: Revised quarterly estimate of gross domestic product (GDP) for the UK. Uses additional data to provide a more precise indication of economic growth than the first estimate.
description.title: GDP quarterly national accounts, UK
description.metaDescription: Revised quarterly estimate of UK gross domestic product (GDP). This gives a more precise indication of economic growth than the first estimate.
description.headline1: UK gross domestic product (GDP) in volume terms was estimated to have increased by 0.4% between Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018 and Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018, unrevised from the first quarterly estimate of GDP.
description.headline2: Growth in the latest quarter was driven by the services sector, which increased by 0.6%, due partly to an increase in retail sales.
description.headline3: Household spending grew by 0.4%, while business investment decreased by 0.7% between Quarter 1 2018 and Quarter 2 2018.

description.summary: A measure of cross-border transactions between the UK and rest of the world. Includes trade, income, capital transfers and foreign assets and liabilities.
description.title: Balance of payments, UK
description.metaDescription: A measure of cross-border transactions between the UK and rest of the world. Includes trade, income, capital transfers and foreign assets and liabilities.
description.headline1: The UK’s current account deficit was £20.3 billion (3.9% of gross domestic product (GDP)) in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018, a widening of £4.6 billion from a revised deficit of £15.7 billion (3.0% of GDP) in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018 and the widest deficit since Quarter 2 2017.
description.headline2: The UK’s current account deficit widened in Quarter 2 2018, due mainly to a widening of the trade in goods and primary income deficits.
description.headline3: The total trade in goods deficit widened by £2.7 billion to £34.7 billion in Quarter 2 2018, from £32.0 billion in Quarter 1 2018, the largest increase to the deficit since Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2016 (£8.0 billion); this can be partly attributed to movements in erratics, which include aircraft and non-monetary gold, and an increase in the price of oil.

description.summary: Estimates of short-term indicators of investment in non-financial assets; business investment and asset and sector breakdowns of total gross fixed capital formation.
description.title: Business investment in the UK
description.metaDescription: Estimates of short-term indicators of investment in non-financial assets; business investment and total gross fixed capital formation.
description.headline1: Gross fixed capital formation (GFCF), in volume terms, was estimated to have fallen by 0.5% to £85.2 billion in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018 from £85.6 billion in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018.
description.headline2: Business investment was estimated to have fallen by 0.7% to £47.5 billion between Quarter 1 2018 and Quarter 2 2018.
description.headline3: Between Quarter 2 2017 and Quarter 2 2018, GFCF was estimated to have fallen by 0.6% from £85.8 billion; business investment was estimated to have fallen by 0.2% from £47.6 billion.

description.summary: Detailed estimates of quarterly sector accounts that can be found in the UK Economic Accounts (UKEA).
description.title: Quarterly sector accounts, UK
description.metaDescription: Aggregate economic indicators and summary estimates for institutional sectors of the UK economy.
description.headline1: In Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018 real household disposable income grew for a second consecutive quarter at 0.4%, compared with an upwardly revised 0.7% in the previous quarter.
description.headline2: The households’ saving ratio increased to 3.9% in the latest quarter, the fourth-lowest since records began in 1963.
description.headline3: Households are now net borrowers for a seventh consecutive quarter (at £7.2 billion), while corporations increase their borrowing requirements by £11.7 billion in the latest quarter.

description.summary: Household final consumption expenditure (HHFCE) for the UK, as a measure of economic growth. Includes all spending on goods and services by members of UK households.
keywords: classification of individual consumption by purpose
description.title: Consumer trends, UK
description.metaDescription: Household final consumption expenditure (HHFCE) for the UK, as a measure of economic growth. Includes all spending on goods and services by members of UK households.
description.headline1: In Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018, household spending (adjusted for inflation) grew by 0.4% compared with Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018.
description.headline2: The main contributor to growth was miscellaneous goods and services, which increased by 1.5% compared with Quarter 1 2018.
description.headline3: Household spending grew by 1.6% in Quarter 2 2018 compared with Quarter 2 2017.

description.summary: The Business Register and Employment Survey (BRES) is the official source of employee and employment estimates by detailed geography and industry.
description.title: UK Business Register and Employment Survey
description.metaDescription: The Business Register and Employment Survey (BRES) is the official source of employee and employment estimates by detailed geography and industry.
description.headline1: The number of employees in the UK increased by 352,800 (1.2%) between 2016 and 2017, from 30.0 million to 30.3 million.
description.headline2: Between 2016 and 2017, the total number of employees increased in all regions except the South East, which decreased by 44,200 (1.1%) and Wales, which decreased by 14,300 (1.1%); London again showed the greatest increase in terms of the total number of employees, with 115,100 (2.3%).
description.headline3: In percentage terms, the strongest growth was in the West Midlands, up 2.9% (73,100), and the North East, up 2.6% (27,200).

description.summary: Estimates of life satisfaction, feeling that the things done in life are worthwhile, happiness and anxiety at the UK, country, regional and local authority level.
description.title: Personal well-being in the UK
description.metaDescription: Estimates of life satisfaction, feeling that the things done in life are worthwhile, happiness and anxiety at the UK, country, regional and local authority level.
description.headline1: The average ratings across the four measures of personal well-being in the UK were unchanged.
description.headline2: Average ratings of feeling the things done in life are worthwhile increased in Scotland; this was driven by a higher percentage of people reporting very high levels for this measure.
description.headline3: Compared with the UK, a larger percentage of people in Wales reported low levels of worthwhile and happiness; interestingly, a larger proportion of people in Wales reported both low levels of life satisfaction but also very high levels of life satisfaction, suggesting greater disparity in life satisfaction in Wales compared with the UK overall.

description.summary: Annual divorce numbers and rates, by duration of marriage, sex, age, previous marital status, and to whom granted and reason.
description.title: Divorces in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Dissolutions and annulments of marriage by previous marital status, sex, age, facts proven and to whom granted.
description.headline1: There were 101,669 divorces of opposite-sex couples in England and Wales in 2017, a decrease of 4.9% compared with 2016, but similar to the number seen in 2015 (101,055).
description.headline2: There were 338 divorces of same-sex couples in 2017, more than three times the number in 2016 (112 divorces); three-quarters (74%) of same-sex couples divorcing in 2017 were female.
description.headline3: In 2017, there were 8.4 divorces of opposite-sex couples per 1,000 married men and women aged 16 years and over (divorce rates), representing the lowest divorce rates since 1973 and a 5.6% decrease from 2016.

description.summary: Annual mid-year population estimates for people aged 90 years and over by sex and single year of age (90 to 104) and 105 years and over, and comparisons between UK countries.
description.title: Estimates of the very old, including centenarians, UK
description.metaDescription: Annual mid-year population estimates for people aged 90 years and over by sex and single year of age (90 to 104) and 105 years and over, and comparisons between UK countries.
description.headline1: In 2017 there were 579,776 people aged 90 years and over living in the UK, including 14,430 centenarians.
description.headline2: The 90 years and over population continues to increase despite a decline in births in England and Wales 90 years ago; this reflects improvements in mortality going back many decades.
description.headline3: The number of centenarians decreased slightly between 2016 and 2017, reflecting low numbers of births during World War One, but is expected to continue to increase again from 2019.

description.summary: Trends in the average number of years people will live beyond their current age measured by period life expectancy, analysed by age and sex for the UK and its constituent countries.
description.title: National life tables, UK
description.metaDescription: Trends in the average number of years people will live beyond their current age measured by period life expectancy, analysed by age and sex for the UK and its constituent countries.

description.summary: House prices and number of transactions for property sales in England and Wales, on an annual basis, updated quarterly.
description.title: House price statistics for small areas in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: House prices and number of transactions for property sales in England and Wales, on an annual basis, updated quarterly.
description.headline1: The median price paid for residential properties in Lower layer Super Output Areas in England and Wales ranged from £24,000 (within County Durham) to £7.7 million (within Barnet).
description.headline2: The number of residential property transactions recorded by HM Land Registry in England and Wales rose by 0.74% to 871,194 in the year ending March 2018.
description.headline3: In London, East and the South East, the number of property transactions for flats decreased whilst transactions of houses increased in the year ending March 2018.

description.summary: Most popular first names for baby boys and girls in 2017 using birth registration data.
description.title: Baby names in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Most popular first names for baby boys and girls in 2017 using birth registration data.
description.headline1: Oliver remained the most popular first name given to baby boys in England and Wales in 2017, a position held since 2013; Harry and George have remained in second and third places respectively since 2016.
description.headline2: Olivia remained the most popular first name given to baby girls in 2017, a position held since 2016; Amelia remained in second place and Isla moved up to third.
description.headline3: Leo replaced Thomas in the top 10 for boys, whilst Hunter and Ralph replaced Aaron and Jasper in the top 100 in 2017.

description.summary: Indication of the future number of households in England and its regions and local authorities.
description.title: Household projections in England
description.metaDescription: Indication of the future number of households in England and its regions and local authorities.
description.headline1: The number of households in England is projected to increase by 4.0 million (17%) over the next 25 years, from 22.9 million in 2016 to 26.9 million in 2041.
description.headline2: While the number of households is projected to grow, it is not expected to grow by as much as was previously projected.
description.headline3: Households headed by someone aged 65 years and over account for 88% of the total growth in households between 2016 and 2041.

description.summary: Investment choices of financial institutions based on financial transactions (investments and disinvestments), including balance sheet data for short-term assets and liabilities, and income and expenditure data.
description.title: MQ5: Investment by insurance companies, pension funds and trusts
description.metaDescription: Quarterly net investment, balance sheet and income and expenditure data. All data are reported on a current price basis (effects of price changes included).
description.headline1: Net disinvestment of £3 billion was reported by insurance companies, pension funds and trusts in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018; in terms of context, the five-year quarterly average for this series is net investment of £7 billion.
description.headline2: In Quarter 2 2018, insurance companies, pension funds and trusts reported net disinvestment in overseas ordinary shares (£15 billion) and UK ordinary shares (£10 billion); this was offset in part by net investment of £7 billion in other overseas corporate securities (mainly corporate bonds), £6 billion in other UK corporate securities and £4 billion in overseas government securities.
description.headline3: In Quarter 2 2018, the net investment by unit trusts and property unit trusts in other overseas corporate securities (mainly corporate bonds) of £7 billion was the largest since the start of this series in 1986.

description.summary: Changes in the costs of employing labour, analysed by sector and industry.
description.title: Index of labour costs per hour, UK
description.metaDescription: Changes in the costs of employing labour, analysed by sector and industry.
description.headline1: The whole economy Index of Labour Costs per Hour (ILCH), seasonally adjusted, increased by 3.2% in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018, compared with Quarter 2 2017.
description.headline2: Wage costs per hour worked increased by 3.1% and estimated non-wage costs per hour worked increased by 3.7% in Quarter 2 2018, compared with Quarter 2 2017.
description.headline3: Compared with Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018, the whole economy ILCH increased by 0.2%; wage costs increased by 0.4% and non-wage costs decreased by 0.4% per hour.

description.summary: The official measure of people employed in the UK public sector, including private sector estimates, based on the difference between total UK employment and public sector employment.
description.title: Public sector employment, UK
description.metaDescription: The official measure of people employed in the UK public sector, including private sector estimates.
description.headline1: For June 2018, there were 5.34 million people employed in the public sector, 4,000 fewer than for March 2018; this small fall was entirely due to the transfer of Welsh housing associations to the private sector.
description.headline2: Excluding the Welsh housing associations transfer, the number of people employed in the public sector increased by 16,000 between March and June 2018.
description.headline3: Between June 2017 and June 2018, public sector employment fell by 122,000; this large fall was entirely due to the transfer of housing associations in England (in December 2017) and in Wales (in June 2018) to the private sector.

description.summary: Occupational pension provision in the UK, providing summary data on membership of schemes and contributions paid.
description.title: Occupational Pensions Schemes Survey, UK
description.metaDescription: Occupational pension provision in the UK, providing summary data on membership of schemes and contributions paid.
description.headline1: Total membership of occupational pension schemes in the UK was an estimated 41.1 million in 2017, compared with 39.2 million in 2016 and is the highest level recorded by the survey.
description.headline2: Total membership of public sector pension schemes was 15.5 million in 2017, compared with 14.8 million in 2016.
description.headline3: Active membership of occupational pension schemes was 15.1 million in 2017, split between the private sector (8.8 million) and the public sector (6.3 million).

description.summary: Registered deaths in the UK from suicide analysed by sex, age, area of usual residence of the deceased and suicide method.
description.title: Suicides in the UK
description.metaDescription: Registered deaths in the UK from suicide analysed by sex, age, area of usual residence of the deceased and suicide method.
description.headline1: In 2017 there were 5,821 suicides registered in the UK, an age-standardised rate of 10.1 deaths per 100,000 population.
description.headline2: The UK male suicide rate of 15.5 deaths per 100,000 was the lowest since our time-series began in 1981; for females, the UK rate was 4.9 deaths per 100,000, this remains consistent with the rates seen in the last 10 years.
description.headline3: Males accounted for three-quarters of suicides registered in 2017 (4,382 deaths), which has been the case since the mid-1990s.

description.summary: Transactions which result in a change of ultimate control of the target company and have a value of £1 million or more.
description.title: Mergers and acquisitions involving UK companies
description.metaDescription: Estimates of the value and number of mergers, acquisitions and disposals involving UK companies worth £1 million or more.
description.headline1: The value of inward mergers and acquisitions (M&A) in Quarter 2 (Apr to June) 2018 was £6.5 billion, £15.8 billion lower than in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018 – mainly reflecting the absence of high-value transactions seen in previous periods.
description.headline2: Outward M&A deal values fell to £1.9 billion in Quarter 2 2018, down from £2.5 billion during Quarter 1 2018 – their lowest level since Quarter 3 (July to Sept) 2013.
description.headline3: The value of domestic M&A was £4.0 billion in Quarter 2 2018, £2.0 billion lower than the previous quarter and the first quarterly decline since Quarter 4 (Oct to Dec) 2016.

description.summary: Annual statistics on the value of turnover from services provided by the UK service economy, Annual Survey of Goods and Services.
description.title: Annual Survey of Goods and Services, UK
description.metaDescription: Annual statistics on the value of turnover from services provided from the UK service economy.
description.headline1: This article provides detailed product-by-industry proportion estimates using Annual Survey of Goods and Services (ASGS) data for the first time.
description.headline2: The majority of turnover generated by the UK service economy came from businesses in the wholesale and retail trade industrial section (45.3%).
description.headline3: The gambling and betting industrial section was the least diverse, with most of the products provided being from the gambling and betting industry itself (96.2%).

description.summary: The economic status of households and the people living in them.
description.title: Working and workless households in the UK
description.metaDescription: The economic status of households and the people living in them.
description.headline1: Of the 20.9 million households (where at least one member is aged 16 to 64 years) in the UK, 12.2 million (58.5%) had all household members aged 16 years and over in employment, up 260,000 or 0.7 percentage points over the past year.
description.headline2: There were 5.7 million households (27.2%) with a mix of at least one working and one workless adult, down 48,000 or 0.5 percentage points over the year.
description.headline3: There were 3.0 million households (14.3%) where no member of the household was in employment, down 11,000 or 0.2 percentage points over the last year.

description.summary: Annual estimates of the market value of financial and non-financial assets for the UK, providing a measure of the nation's wealth.
description.title: The UK national balance sheet estimates
description.metaDescription: Annual estimates of the market value of financial and non-financial assets for the UK, providing a measure of the nation's wealth.
description.headline1: In 2017, the UK’s net worth was estimated at £10.2 trillion; an average of £155,000 per person.
description.headline2: Growth in the UK’s net worth was estimated at 5.1% between 2016 and 2017, which was in line with average growth between 2009 and 2017 of 5.2%.
description.headline3: UK net worth more than trebled between 1995 and 2017, but much of this was from growth in the value of land.

description.summary: Annual statistics on live births. Includes countries of birth for non-UK born mothers and fathers.
keywords: birthplace,foreign born mothers and fathers,non-uk born,live births,fertility rates
description.title: Births by parents’ country of birth, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Annual statistics on live births. Includes countries of birth for non-UK born mothers and fathers.
description.headline1: In 2017 in England and Wales, 28.4% of live-born babies had mothers who were born outside the UK, up from 28.2% in 2016; this is the highest percentage on record since 1969 when country of birth was first collected at birth registration.
description.headline2: In 2017, there were 486,417 live births to women born in the UK and 192,651 live births to women born outside the UK, decreasing by 2.7% and 1.8% respectively compared with 2016.
description.headline3: In 2017, there were 486,417 live births to women born in the UK and 192,651 live births to women born outside the UK, decreasing by 2.7% and 1.8% respectively compared with 2016.

description.summary: A summary of the latest official long-term international migration statistics for the UK for the year ending March 2018, published by Office for National Statistics (ONS). Data from the Home Office and the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) are also included.
description.title: Migration Statistics Quarterly Report
description.metaDescription: Immigration to the UK and emigration from the UK, including net migration (the difference between immigration and emigration).
description.headline1: To fully understand migration, we need to consider all available data sources. On this basis, our best assessment is that around 270,000 more people came to the UK than left in the year ending March 2018, so long-term net migration has continued to add to the UK population.
description.headline2: Net migration has fallen from the peak levels seen in 2015 and 2016 and has remained broadly stable since. Underlying this period of stability, long-term immigration and long-term emigration have remained broadly stable at around 610,000 and 340,000 respectively in the year ending March 2018.
description.headline3: Although the estimates show an increase in long-term net migration over the latest year, this was due to an unusual decrease in the International Passenger Survey estimates for student immigration in 2016, that was not seen in other data sources, and which our quality work suggested was an anomaly. We therefore do not recommend that users make year-on-year comparisons over this period and instead look at the broader evidence and longer time series.

description.summary: Estimates of young people (aged 16 to 24 years) who are not in education, employment or training, by age and sex.
description.title: Young people not in education, employment or training (NEET), UK
description.metaDescription: Estimates of young people (aged 16 to 24 years) who are not in education, employment or training, by age and sex.
description.headline1: There were 783,000 young people (aged 16 to 24 years) in the UK who were not in education, employment or training (NEET); this number decreased by 25,000 from January to March 2018 and was down 6,000 when compared with April to June 2017.
description.headline2: The percentage of all young people in the UK who were NEET was 11.2%; the proportion was down 0.3 percentage points from January to March 2018 and up 0.1 percentage points from April to June 2017.
description.headline3: Of all young people in the UK who were NEET, 37.4% were looking for work and available for work and therefore classified as unemployed; the remainder were either not looking for work and/or not available for work and therefore classified as economically inactive.

description.summary: Annual estimates of the value and types of non-financial assets used in the production of goods or services within the UK economy and their loss in value over time.
description.title: Capital stocks and fixed capital consumption, UK
description.metaDescription: Annual estimates of the value and types of non-financial assets used in the production of goods or services within the UK economy and their loss in value over time.
description.headline1: The UK’s net capital stock was estimated at £4.6 trillion at the end of 2017, increasing by 1.1% compared with 2016.
description.headline2: Prior to the economic downturn, net capital stock increased on average by 2.0% per year, slowing to an average of 1.3% per year since 2010.
description.headline3: Growth in the net capital stock of dwellings has still not recovered to the average growth rate prior to the economic downturn.

description.summary: Annual data on sudden infant deaths in England and Wales and infant deaths for which the cause remained unascertained after a full investigation, with associated risk factors.
description.title: Unexplained deaths in infancy, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Annual data on sudden infant deaths in England and Wales and infant deaths for which the cause remained unascertained after a full investigation, with associated risk factors.
description.headline1: There were 219 unexplained infant deaths in England and Wales in 2016, an increase compared with 2015 (195), but still lower than in 2006 (285).
description.headline2: In 2016, the unexplained infant mortality rate rose to 0.31 deaths per 1,000 live births, however, the rate was not significantly higher than the 2015 rate (0.28) but was significantly lower than in 2006 (0.43).
description.headline3: Unexplained infant deaths accounted for 8.3% of all infant deaths occurring in 2016, compared with 7.6% in 2015.

description.summary: Annual statistics on formations and dissolutions of civil partnerships analysed by the sex, age, and previous marital status of the couples and the place of registration.
description.title: Civil partnerships in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Annual statistics on formations and dissolutions of civil partnerships analysed by the sex, age, and previous marital status of the couples and the place of registration.
description.headline1: There were 908 civil partnerships formed in England and Wales in 2017, an increase of 2.0% compared with 2016; this is the second annual increase since the introduction of marriages of same-sex couples was announced in 2013.
description.headline2: Almost two-thirds (66%) of all civil partnerships formed in 2017 were between men.
description.headline3: The increase in the number of civil partnership formations between 2016 and 2017 resulted solely from an 8.0% rise (23 civil partnerships) in civil partnerships between women, civil partnership formation among men decreased by 0.8% (five civil partnerships).

description.summary: Internet access in Great Britain, including how many people have internet, how they access it and what they use it for.
description.title: Internet access – households and individuals, Great Britain
description.metaDescription: Internet access in Great Britain, including how many people have internet, how they access it and what they use it to do.
description.headline1: 89% of adults in Great Britain used the internet at least weekly in 2018, up from 88% in 2017 and 51% in 2006
description.headline2: 46% of adults watched videos on demand from commercial services in 2018, up from 29% in 2016.
description.headline3: 46% of adults watched videos on demand from commercial services in 2018, up from 29% in 2016.

description.summary: Deaths related to drug poisoning in England and Wales from 1993 onwards, by cause of death, sex, age and substances involved in the death.
description.title: Deaths related to drug poisoning in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Deaths related to drug poisoning in England and Wales from 1993 onwards, by cause of death, sex, age and substances involved in the death.
description.headline1: There were 3,756 deaths relating to drug poisoning in England and Wales in 2017, a rate of 66.1 deaths per 1 million population, and similar to levels seen in 2016.
description.headline2: Two-thirds of drug-related deaths were related to drug misuse, accounting for 43.7 deaths per 1 million in 2017.
description.headline3: Males’ mortality rate decreased from 91.4 deaths per 1 million population in 2016 to 89.6 in 2017, while the female rate increased for the eighth consecutive year to 42.9 deaths per 1 million population; neither changes were significant.

description.summary: Employment statistics for the Civil Service population, providing regional analyses, diversity and earnings data.
description.title: Civil Service statistics, UK
description.metaDescription: Presents Civil Service employment statistics, which provide regional analyses, diversity and earnings statistics for the Civil Service population.
description.headline1: Civil Service employment on 31 March 2018 was 430,075, up 10,676 (2.5%) on 31 March 2017.
description.headline2: There were 331,392 full-time civil servants, 10,229 (3.2%) more than 31 March 2017 and the number of civil servants working part-time increased by 447 (0.5%) to 98,683.
description.headline3: Of those who declared their ethnicity, 12.0% were from an ethnic minority.

description.summary: Annual information at a local level about households and the adults and children living in them, by their economic activity status.
description.title: Workless households for regions across the UK
description.metaDescription: Annual information at a local level about households and the adults and children living in them, by their economic activity status.
description.headline1: In 2017, the areas with the highest percentage of workless households were generally located outside the south of England.
description.headline2: Not all locations outside the south of England had high percentages of workless households; 8 of the 50 areas with the lowest percentages in 2017 were in Scotland, Wales, the Midlands and the north of England.
description.headline3: Hartlepool was the only area in the top five areas with the highest percentage of workless households in both 2016 and 2017.

description.summary: Balances between inward and outward transactions, providing a net flow of transactions between UK residents and the rest of the world and reports on how that flow is funded.
description.title: UK Balance of Payments, The Pink Book
description.metaDescription: Balances between inward and outward transactions, providing a net flow of transactions between UK residents and the rest of the world and reports on how that flow is funded.
description.headline1: The UK current account deficit narrowed in 2017 to 3.9% of nominal gross domestic product (GDP) from a record 5.2% in 2016, the narrowest deficit since 2012.
description.headline2: The narrowing in the current account deficit in 2017 was mostly caused by a narrowing in the primary income deficit from 2.5% to 1.6% of GDP which was driven by an improvement in net foreign direct investment (FDI) income.
description.headline3: The trade deficit narrowed from 1.6% to 1.3% of GDP due to a widening in the services surplus which was driven by a widening in the financial services surplus and a narrowing in the travel services deficit.

description.summary: Annual estimates of population by legal marital status and cohabitation status by age and sex for England and Wales.
description.title: Population estimates by marital status and living arrangements, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Annual estimates of population by legal marital status and cohabitation status by age and sex for England and Wales.
description.headline1: The proportion of the population of England and Wales aged 16 years and over who were married in 2017 (51.0%) has remained broadly unchanged since 2010, but has reduced slightly since 2002 (54.8%).
description.headline2: The single, never married population aged 16 years and over in England and Wales increased by 3.9 million from 2002 to 2017 whilst the number of married people only increased by 1.2 million over the same period.
description.headline3: One in eight people aged 16 years and over in England and Wales in 2017 were cohabiting, continuing a steadily-increasing trend since 2002.

description.summary: Early and provisional estimates of median equivalised disposable income and measures of income inequality, ahead of revised estimates published in the annual article Effects of taxes and benefits on UK household income: disposable income estimate.
description.title: Effects of taxes and benefits on UK household income – flash estimate
description.metaDescription: Early and provisional estimates of median equivalised disposable income and measures of income inequality.
description.headline1: This release presents provisional estimates of median equivalised disposable income and measures of income inequality in the UK, for the financial year ending (FYE) 2018.
description.headline2: The provisional estimate of median household disposable income for FYE 2018 is £28,400, an increase of £300 (1.2%) compared with FYE 2017 after accounting for inflation and household composition; this is slower than the 2.4% growth recorded in FYE 2017.
description.headline3: Median disposable income of retired households increased by £300 (1.4%) compared with £200 for non-retired households (0.6%).

description.summary: Live births, stillbirths and the intensity of childbearing, measured by the total fertility rate.
description.title: Births in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Live births, stillbirths and the intensity of childbearing, measured by the total fertility rate.
description.headline1: There were 679,106 live births in England and Wales in 2017, a decrease of 2.5% from 2016 and the lowest number of live births since 2006.
description.headline2: In 2017, the total fertility rate (TFR) declined for the fifth consecutive year to 1.76 children per woman, from 1.81 in 2016.
description.headline3: Fertility rates decreased for every age group in 2017, except for women aged 40 years and over, where rates increased by 1.3% to 16.1 births per 1,000 women in that age group, reaching the highest level since 1949.

description.summary: Annual data on death registrations, contains death rates, cause of death data by sex and age, and death registrations by area of residence and single year of age.
description.title: Deaths registered in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Annual data on death registrations, contains death rates, cause of death data by sex and age, and death registrations by area of residence and single year of age.
description.headline1: There were 533,253 deaths registered in England and Wales in 2017, a 1.6% increase from 2016 and the highest number registered annually since 2003.
description.headline2: Age-standardised mortality rates (ASMRs) decreased for both sexes in 2017; by 0.4% for males and 0.2% for females.
description.headline3: Both the number of deaths and age-specific mortality rates for people aged 90 years and over increased in 2017, by 4.4% and 2.9% respectively; most notably for females.

description.summary: Measuring the contribution of the environment to the economy, the impact of economic activity on the environment, and society's response to environmental issues. Satellite accounts to the main UK National Accounts.
description.title: UK Environmental Accounts
description.metaDescription: The contribution of the environment to the economy, the impact of economic activity on the environment, and society's response to environmental issues.
description.headline1: The continued switch from coal to natural gas by the energy supply and manufacturing sectors resulted in a fall in overall greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in 2016, the continuation of a long-term trend.
description.headline2: In 2016, households were the biggest emitter of GHGs, accounting for one-quarter of total UK GHG emissions.
description.headline3: In 2016, the UK consumed 570 million tonnes of material, still below pre-2008 levels.

description.summary: Initial natural capital accounts containing information about green space in urban areas.
description.title: UK natural capital
description.metaDescription: Initial natural capital accounts containing information about green space in urban areas.
description.headline1: - On average, almost a third of urban area in Great Britain consists of natural land and green space.
description.headline2: - There are over 62,000 urban green space sites in Great Britain adapted for a specific function e.g. public gardens and parks.
description.headline3: - This urban natural land and green space provides society with many services including protecting urban properties from noise pollution and cooling cities by over half a degree Celsius.

description.summary: Cigarette smoking habits among adults in the UK, including the proportion of people who smoke, demographic breakdowns, changes over time, and use of e-cigarettes.
description.title: Adult smoking habits in the UK
description.metaDescription: Data using the Annual Population Survey for UK and Opinions and Lifestyle Survey for Great Britain. Smoking prevalence by age and sex, daily cigarette consumption and smokers who have quit. Also e-cigarette use and vaping.
description.headline1: In the UK, 15.1% of people aged 18 years and above smoked cigarettes, which equates to around 7.4 million people in the population, based on our estimate from the Annual Population Survey.
description.headline2: Of the constituent countries, 14.9% of adults in England smoked; for Wales, this figure was 16.1%; Scotland, 16.3% and Northern Ireland, 16.5%.

contact.name: Ben Windsor-Shellard, Laura Pullin and Marie Horton

description.headline3: In the UK, 17.0% of men smoked compared with 13.3% of women.

description.summary: National and subnational mid-year population estimates for the UK and its constituent countries by administrative area, age, sex and components of population change.
description.title: Population estimates for the UK, England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland
description.metaDescription: National and subnational mid-year population estimates for the UK and its constituent countries by administrative area, age, sex and components of population change.
description.headline1: The population of the UK at 30 June 2017 exceeded 66 million people (66,040,229), an increase of 392,000 people since mid-2016.
description.headline2: This growth rate (0.6%) is the lowest since mid-2004.
description.headline3: 41% of the population growth occurred from natural change (births minus deaths), 59% through net international migration and an increase of 2,700 people in the armed forces population based in the UK.

description.summary: Analysis of how household incomes in the UK are affected by direct and indirect taxes and benefits received in cash or kind, and the changing levels of income inequality over time.
description.title: Effects of taxes and benefits on UK household income
description.metaDescription: Analysis of how household incomes in the UK are affected by taxation and benefits, and the changing levels of income inequality over time.
description.headline1: This release presents analysis on the effects of taxes and benefits on UK household income, extending the analysis presented in Household disposable income and inequality in the UK: financial year ending 2017 to include indirect taxes and benefits-in-kind.
description.headline2: This analysis is based on the Office for National Statistics’s (ONS’s) Living Costs and Food Survey.
description.headline3: In the financial year ending 2017, the average income of the richest fifth of households before taxes and benefits was £88,800 per year, 12 times greater than that of the poorest fifth (£7,400 per year).

description.summary: Science, engineering and technology (SET) annual expenditure by UK government departments, research councils and higher education funding councils. Also includes indicative UK contributions to EU research and development expenditure.
description.title: Government expenditure on science, engineering and technology, UK
description.metaDescription: Science, engineering and technology (SET) expenditure by the UK government and indicative UK contributions to the EU’s research and development expenditure.
description.headline1: The UK government’s expenditure on science, engineering and technology (SET) continued to grow in 2016, expanding £0.1 billion to £11.5 billion, an increase of 1.2%.
description.headline2: The 2016 SET estimate consists of expenditure on research and development (R&D) of £10.3 billion, UK contributions to EU R&D expenditure of £0.9 billion and knowledge transfer of £0.3 billion.
description.headline3: The UK research councils contributed the most to expenditure on SET in 2016 at £3.4 billion, 30% of the total.

description.summary: Long-term survival trends for children (aged 0 to 14 years) diagnosed with cancer in England. Adult and stage of diagnosis survival estimates will be published in a separate release, later in 2018.
description.title: Cancer survival in England – childhood
description.metaDescription: Long-term survival trends for children (aged 0 to 14 years) diagnosed with cancer in England.
description.headline1: Cancer survival in children (aged 0 to 14 years) continues to improve for all cancers combined; the general increasing trend of 5-year survival has continued, from 77.1% in 2001 to 84.0% predicted for those diagnosed in 2017; a similar increasing trend has also been observed for both 1-year and 10-year survival.
description.headline2: The increases in 1-year, 5-year and 10-year survival have been observed in each of the age groups 0 to 4 years, 5 to 9 years and 10 to 14 years.
description.headline3: Since there is a small difference between 5-year and 10-year survival estimates, children who survive for five years often live at least a further five years after diagnosis.

description.summary: Cancer diagnoses and age-standardised incidence rates for all types of cancer by age, sex and region including breast, prostate, lung and colorectal cancer.
description.title: Cancer registration statistics, England
description.metaDescription: Cancer diagnoses and age-standardised incidence rates for all types of cancer by age, sex and region including breast, prostate, lung and colorectal cancer.
description.headline1: The number of new cases of cancer in England continues to rise and, in 2016, there were 303,135 cancers registered (excluding non-melanoma skin cancers); this is equivalent to 828 new cases being diagnosed each day during 2016.
description.headline2: Breast (15.2%), prostate (13.4%), lung (12.7%) and colorectal (11.5%) cancers continue to account for over half of the cancer registrations in England for all ages combined.
description.headline3: More cancers were registered in males (155,019) than females (148,116) and across the majority of cancer sites, more males were diagnosed with cancer than females; this is a persistent feature of the data, as reported in previous cancer registration years.

description.summary: Internet use in the UK annual estimates by age, sex, disability and geographical location.
description.title: Internet users, UK
description.metaDescription: Internet use in the UK annual estimates by age, sex, disability and geographical location.
description.headline1: In 2018, 90% of adults in the UK were recent internet users, up from 89% in 2017.
description.headline2: 8.4% of adults had never used the internet in 2018, down from 9.2% in 2017.
description.headline3: Virtually all adults aged 16 to 34 years were recent internet users (99%) in 2018, compared with 44% of adults aged 75 years and over.

description.summary: The second quarterly estimate of GDP based on additional data but produced later than the preliminary estimate, providing a more precise indication of economic growth.
description.title: Second estimate of GDP
description.metaDescription: Estimates of the main components of GDP from the output, income and expenditure approaches.
description.headline1: UK gross domestic product (GDP) in volume terms was estimated to have increased by 0.1% between Quarter 4 (Oct to Dec) 2017 and Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018, unrevised from the preliminary estimate of GDP.
description.headline2: When comparing GDP growth in the most recent quarter to the same quarter a year ago, we see a continuation of a pattern of slowing growth, in part reflecting a slowing in the growth of consumer-facing industries.
description.headline3: The services industries increased by 0.3% in Quarter 1 2018; while construction decreased by 2.7% in Quarter 1 2018.

description.summary: Visits to and from the UK lasting less than 1 year analysed by the main reason for visiting, age, sex, citizenship and country of residence.
description.title: Short-Term International Migration for England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Estimates of short-term international migration to and from the UK for England and Wales, by reason for migration, age, sex and citizenship.
description.headline1: Estimates of Short-Term International Migration are available based on three definitions – one to 12 or 3 to 12 months for all reasons (including “other” reasons such as holidays or visiting family), and the United Nations (UN) definition of 3 to 12 months for work or study only.
description.headline2: In the year to June 2016, twice as many people made short-term visits abroad than to England and Wales for 1 to 12 months; this pattern has been similar since reporting began in the year ending June 2004.
description.headline3: The most common reason for visits to and from England and Wales remains “other”; “other” reasons account for the larger flow of people visiting abroad, who are predominantly British.

description.summary: Latest population estimates for the UK by country of birth and nationality, covering the period from 2004 to the year ending 2017.
description.title: Population of the UK by country of birth and nationality
description.metaDescription: Latest population estimates for the UK by country of birth and nationality.
description.headline1: Non-UK populations continued to increase in 2017; since reporting began in 2004, the non-UK populations of the UK have increased year-on-year as more people continue to come to the UK to live than move to live abroad for a year or more.
description.headline2: The non-UK born population increased from 9.2 million in 2016 to 9.4 million in 2017 (up 3%) and the non-British population increased from 6.0 million to 6.2 million (up 4%).
description.headline3: The increase in non-UK populations in the last few years has been accounted for by EU populations, particularly EU14 and EU2, with those born in Romania, or with Romanian nationality, seeing the largest increases.

description.summary: Indication of the future size and age structure of the population in the regions, local authorities, clinical commissioning groups and NHS regions of England.
description.title: Subnational population projections for England
description.metaDescription: Indication of the future size and age structure of the population in the regions, local authorities, clinical commissioning groups and NHS regions of England.
description.headline1: The populations of all regions in England are projected to grow by mid-2026; regions in the north of England are projected to grow at a slower rate than those in the south.
description.headline2: London is projected to be the fastest growing region; the North East is projected to have the slowest rate of growth.
description.headline3: Nearly all local authorities are projected to grow by mid-2026; the populations of just 15 local authorities are projected to fall.

description.summary: Annual estimates of regional gross disposable household income (GDHI) for UK NUTS1, NUTS2, NUTS3 regions, local and combined authorities.
description.title: Regional gross disposable household income, UK
description.metaDescription: Annual estimates of regional gross disposable household income (GDHI) for UK NUTS1, NUTS2, NUTS3 regions, local and combined authorities.
description.headline1: In 2016, England was the only country of the UK with a gross disposable household income (GDHI) per head above the UK average, but the strongest growth compared with 2015 was in Scotland, at 1.2%.
description.headline2: Of the NUTS1 regions in 2016, London had the highest GDHI per head where, on average, each person had £27,151 available to spend or save; the North East had the lowest at £15,595 and this compares with a UK average of £19,432.
description.headline3: Between 2015 and 2016, GDHI per head of population increased in all NUTS1 regions except the North East and North West, which fell by 0.6% and 0.2% respectively; the largest percentage increase was in the East of England at 1.3%.

description.summary: Size and growth of the UK non-financial sectors within the 12 NUTS1 regions of the UK as estimated by the Annual Business Survey.
description.title: Annual Business Survey, UK non-financial business economy
description.metaDescription: Size and growth of the UK non-financial sectors within the 12 NUTS1 regions of the UK as estimated by the Annual Business Survey.
description.headline1: In 2016, the approximate gross value added at basic prices (aGVA) generated by local activity of the UK non-financial business economy was estimated to be £1,190.9 billion.
description.headline2: Out of the 12 UK regions, 10 experienced growth in aGVA in 2016 compared with 2015; the two regions showing decreases in aGVA were Scotland and the South West where aGVA fell by 4.6% (£4.1 billion) and 2.8% (£2.2 billion) respectively.
description.headline3: The highest percentage increase to local level UK aGVA in 2016 came from Wales, increasing by 11.1% (£3.7 billion) compared with 2015; within Wales the production sector showed the highest growth, increasing by 16.2% (£1.9 billion).

description.summary: Annual data on alcohol consumption by adults, including changes in drinking patterns in recent years and data for those who do not drink.
description.title: Adult drinking habits in Great Britain
description.metaDescription: An omnibus survey that collects information on a range of topics from people living in private households in Great Britain.
