description.headline1: In Great Britain, 57.0% of Opinions and Lifestyle Survey respondents aged 16 years and over in 2017 drank alcohol, which equates to 29.2 million people in the population.
description.headline2: Young people aged 16 to 24 years in Great Britain are less likely to drink than any other age group; when they do drink, consumption on their heaviest drinking day tends to be higher than other ages.
description.headline3: 20.4% of survey respondents reported that they did not drink alcohol at all.

description.summary: Preliminary estimate for gross domestic product (GDP) containing constant price gross value added (GVA) data for the UK. Data are available by industrial sector.
description.title: Gross domestic product, preliminary estimate
description.metaDescription: The first estimate of quarterly GDP based on less data but produced earlier, providing a timely indicator of economic growth.
description.headline1: UK gross domestic product (GDP) was estimated to have increased by 0.1% in Quarter 1 (Jan to Mar) 2018, compared with 0.4% in Quarter 4 (Oct to Dec) 2017.
description.headline2: UK GDP growth was the slowest since Quarter 4 2012, with construction being the largest downward pull on GDP, falling by 3.3%.
description.headline3: Production increased by 0.7%, with manufacturing growth slowing to 0.2%; this was partially offset by an increase in energy production due to the below-average temperatures.

description.summary: Brings together data on house prices and annual earnings to calculate affordability ratios for national and subnational geographies in England and Wales, on an annual basis.
description.title: Housing affordability in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Affordability ratios calculated by dividing house prices by gross annual earnings, based on the median and lower quartiles of both house prices and earnings.
description.headline1: On average, full-time workers could expect to pay around 7.8 times their annual workplace-based earnings on purchasing a home in England and Wales in 2017, a significant increase of 2.4% since 2016.
description.headline2: On average, full-time workers could expect to pay around 7.8 times their annual workplace-based earnings on purchasing a home in England and Wales in 2017, a significant increase of 2.4% since 2016.
description.headline3: On average, full-time workers could expect to pay around 7.8 times their annual workplace-based earnings on purchasing a home in England and Wales in 2017, a significant increase of 2.4% since 2016.

description.summary: Small area model-based income estimates covering middle layer super output areas (MSOAs) in England and Wales.
description.title: Small area model-based income estimates, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Small area model-based income estimates covering middle layer super output areas (MSOAs) in England and Wales.

description.summary: Healthcare expenditure statistics, produced to the international definitions of the System of Health Accounts 2011.
description.title: UK Health Accounts
description.metaDescription: Healthcare expenditure statistics for 2016
description.headline1: Total current healthcare expenditure in 2016 was £191.7 billion, an increase of 3.6% on spending in 2015, when £185.0 billion was spent on healthcare in the UK.
description.headline2: Government-financed healthcare expenditure accounted for 79.4% of total spending, £152.2 billion.
description.headline3: Since 2013, government spending on curative and rehabilitative care in an inpatient setting has grown more slowly than curative and rehabilitative care delivered in outpatient, day case or home setting

description.summary: Deaths from causes that are considered avoidable in the presence of timely and effective healthcare or public health interventions.  Data are based on a revised definition of avoidable mortality (introduced in data year 2014) for all persons and a separate indicator for children and young people.
description.title: Avoidable mortality in the UK
description.metaDescription: Deaths from causes that are considered avoidable in the presence of timely and effective healthcare or public health interventions.
description.headline1: In 2016, approximately 24% of all deaths in the UK were considered avoidable (141,101 deaths out of 597,206).
description.headline2: Scotland had the highest rate of avoidable deaths for males and females compared with the other constituent countries of the UK, whereas England had the lowest rate.
description.headline3: Scotland had the highest rate of avoidable deaths for males and females compared with the other constituent countries of the UK, whereas England had the lowest rate.

description.summary: A comparison of labour productivity across the G7 nations, in terms of levels of and growth in gross domestic product (GDP) per hour worked and GDP per worker.
description.title: International comparisons of UK productivity (ICP), final estimates
description.metaDescription: A comparison of labour productivity across the G7 nations, in terms of levels of and growth in gross domestic product (GDP) per hour worked and GDP per worker.
description.headline1: The UK's long-running nominal productivity gap with the other six G7 economies was broadly unchanged in 2016: falling from 16.4% in 2015 to 16.3% in 2016 in output per hour worked terms.
description.headline2: The UK's nominal productivity gap in output per worker terms narrowed from 16.9% in 2015 to 16.6% in 2016, compared with the average for the rest of the G7.
description.headline3: Compared with the rest of the G7, the UK had below average real productivity growth in both output per hour and output per worker terms in 2016.

description.summary: Annual statistics on conceptions to residents of England and Wales; numbers and rates, by age group including women aged under 18 years.
description.title: Conceptions in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Pregnancies leading to a birth or legal termination by age group, including women aged under 18 years.
description.headline1: The under-18 conception rate in 2016 was 18.9 conceptions per thousand women aged 15 to 17 years; this is the lowest rate recorded since comparable statistics were first produced in 1969.
description.headline2: The estimated number of conceptions to women aged under 18 years fell to 18,076 in 2016, compared with 20,351 in 2015, a decrease of 11%.
description.headline3: The estimated number of conceptions to women aged under 16 years fell to 2,821 in 2016, compared with 3,466 in 2015, a decrease of 19%.

description.summary: Membership and contributions to workplace pension arrangements for UK employees by type, age, industry, public and private sector, occupation and size of company.
description.title: Annual Survey of Hours and Earnings pension tables, UK
description.metaDescription: Membership and contributions to workplace pension arrangements for UK employees by type, age, industry, public and private sector, occupation and size of company.
description.headline1: Employee workplace pension scheme membership has increased to 73% in 2017, from 67% in 2016, driven predominantly by increases in membership of occupational defined contribution schemes (including National Employment Savings Trust) within the private sector.
description.headline2: In 2017, there were 89% of public sector employees who were members of a workplace pension scheme compared with 67% of private sector employees, this gap continues to narrow following the introduction of automatic enrolment in 2012.
description.headline3: Those aged 22 to 29 years had the largest growth in pension membership from 65% in 2016 to 73% in 2017.

description.summary: People registered to vote in Parliamentary and local government elections as recorded in the electoral registers published on 1 December for England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
description.title: Electoral statistics, UK
description.metaDescription: People registered to vote in Parliamentary and local government elections in the UK, as recorded in the electoral registers published on 1 December.
description.headline1: The total number of UK Parliamentary electors increased by 380,000 (0.8%) between December 2016 and December 2017, a smaller increase than in the previous year.
description.headline2: The total number of UK local government electors increased by more than half a million (1.2%) between December 2016 and December 2017.
description.headline3: Of the 650 Parliamentary constituencies in the UK, 480 (74%) had an increase in Parliamentary electors between December 2016 and December 2017.

description.summary: Estimates of research and development performed and funded by business enterprise, higher education, government, research councils, and private non-profit organisations.
description.title: Gross domestic expenditure on research and development, UK
description.metaDescription: Estimates of research and development in business enterprise, higher education, government, which includes research councils and private non-profit organisations.
description.headline1: Research and development (R&D) continued to grow, expanding by £1.4 billion to £33.1 billion in 2016, an increase of 4.3%, above the long-term annual average increase of 4.1% since 1990.
description.headline2: Most of this year’s growth came from the business sector, where it grew by £1.2 billion to £22.2 billion, an increase of 6%.
description.headline3: Total R&D expenditure in the UK in 2016 represented 1.67% of gross domestic product (GDP), unchanged from 2015, remaining below the European Union (EU-28) provisional estimate of 2.03%.

description.summary: Stillbirths, infant and childhood deaths occurring annually in England and Wales, and associated risk factors.
description.title: Child mortality in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Stillbirths, infant and childhood deaths occurring annually in England and Wales, and associated risk factors.
description.headline1: There were 2,651 infant deaths (deaths of those aged under one year) that occurred in England and Wales in 2016, compared with 2,578 in 2015 and 6,313 in 1986.
description.headline2: In 2016, the infant mortality rate increased to 3.8 deaths per 1,000 live births, compared with 3.7 in 2015.
description.headline3: Cancers remain the most common cause of death for children aged 1 to 15 years, accounting for 20.6% of deaths in 2016.

description.summary: Life expectancy and years expected to live in "Good" health using national indices of deprivation to measure socioeconomic inequalities.
description.title: Health state life expectancies by national deprivation deciles, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Life expectancy and years expected to live in "Good" health using national indices of deprivation to measure socioeconomic inequalities.
description.headline1: In England, the least deprived males at birth in 2014 to 2016 could expect to live almost a decade longer than the most deprived (9.3 years), while for females the gap was 7.4 years.
description.headline2: In 2014 to 2016, the least deprived males and females at birth in Wales could expect to live 8.9 years and 7.3 years more than the most deprived, respectively.
description.headline3: Large gaps in longevity by level of deprivation exposure persisted at age 65 years in England and Wales; the gap for men exceeded 4.7 years and the gap for women exceeded 4.6 years.

description.title: Marriages in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Marriages in England and Wales by age, sex, previous marital status and civil or religious ceremony.

description.edition: Adults diagnosed 2011 to 2015 and followed up to 2016
description.title: Geographic patterns of cancer survival in England
description.metaDescription: Cancer survival estimates for England by  NHS Region, Cancer Alliance, Sustainability and Transformation Partnerships.

description.summary: Main results from the fifth wave of the Wealth and Assets Survey covering the period July 2014 to June 2016.
description.title: Wealth in Great Britain Wave 5
description.metaDescription: Main results from the fifth wave of the Wealth and Assets Survey covering the period July 2014 to June 2016.

description.summary: Final results from the Low Carbon and Renewable Energy Survey on the low carbon and renewable energy economy in the UK, including direct and indirect activity, employees and turnover.
description.title: UK Environmental Accounts: Low Carbon and Renewable Energy Economy Survey
description.metaDescription: The low carbon and renewable energy economy in the UK, including direct and indirect activity, employees and turnover.
description.headline1: The UK low carbon and renewable energy (LCRE) economy grew by 5.0% to £42.6 billion in 2016, from £40.5 billion in 2015; it continued to account for around 1% of total UK non-financial turnover.
description.headline2: The number of employees working directly in the LCRE economy in the UK, grew by 3.3% to 208,000 full-time equivalents (FTE) in 2016, from 201,500 in 2015; it continued to account for around 1% of total UK non-financial employees.
description.headline3: The energy efficient product group accounted for almost half of total LCRE turnover (£20.7 billion) and over two-thirds of LCRE employment (141,500 FTE) in 2016.

description.summary: Product, industry and geographic breakdowns of imports and exports of services, excluding travel, transport and banking sectors.
description.title: International trade in services, UK
description.metaDescription: Product, industry and geographic breakdowns of imports and exports of services, excluding travel, transport and banking sectors.
description.headline1: Total UK exports of services (excluding travel, transport and banking) showed record growth in 2016, rising from £123.2 billion in 2015 to £142.7 billion in 2016, an increase of 15.8%.
description.headline2: Total UK imports of services (excluding travel, transport and banking) also showed record growth in 2016 and rose by £10.2 billion to a total of £68.7 billion, an increase of 17.5%.
description.headline3: The information and communication sector showed the largest growth in 2016 for both UK exports and imports of services in 2016, rising by £6.5 billion and £5.1 billion respectively.

description.summary: An insight into the spending habits of UK households, broken down by household characteristics and types of spending.
description.title: Family spending in the UK
description.metaDescription: An insight into the spending habits of UK households, broken down by household characteristics and types of spending.
description.headline1: Average weekly household spending rose to £554.20 in the financial year ending 2017; in real terms, this was a return to pre-economic downturn levels.
description.headline2: Households spent an average of £79.70 a week on transport, an increase of £5.40 in real terms when compared with the previous year; this makes transport the top spending category.
description.headline3: When comparing between English regions and UK constituent countries, average weekly household spending differed by more than £200.

description.summary: Initial insight into main estimates of household incomes and inequality in the UK, along with analysis of how these measures have changed over time accounting for inflation and household composition.
description.title: Household disposable income and inequality in the UK
description.metaDescription: How taxes and benefits redistribute income between various groups of households in the UK.
description.headline1: Based on the Office for National Statistics’s (ONS’s) Living Costs and Food Survey, the UK median disposable household income was £27,300 in the financial year ending (FYE) 2017, up 2.3% on the previous year (after accounting for inflation and household composition).
description.headline2: The latest estimate of UK median disposable household income is very similar to the nowcast estimate of £27,200 for FYE 2017, published in July 2017.
description.headline3: Growth in median disposable income for the richest fifth of households has lagged behind households in the rest of the income distribution in recent years, but has now recovered to the levels seen before the start of the economic downturn, taking into account inflation and changes in household composition.

GVA(B) is measured at current basic prices, which include the effect of inflation. description.title: Foreign direct investment involving UK companies
description.metaDescription: A detailed breakdown of UK foreign direct investment flows, positions (stocks) and earnings (both inward and outward), by country, component and industry.

description.summary: Use of information and communication technology (ICT) and the value of e-commerce activity by UK businesses.
description.title: E-commerce and ICT activity, UK
description.metaDescription: Use of information and communication technology (ICT) and the value of e-commerce activity by UK businesses.
description.headline1: E-commerce sales by businesses in the UK non-financial sector were £511 billion in 2016, up from £503 billion in 2015.
description.headline2: E-commerce sales were made up of £236 billion website sales and £274 electronic data interchange (EDI) sales (business-to-business sales).
description.headline3: While 62% of businesses with 1,000 or more employees benefit from superfast broadband, with an internet speed of 100 megabits per second (Mbps) or more, only 5.8% of businesses with less than 10 employees had this internet speed.

description.summary: One-year cancer survival for all-cancers combined; for breast, colorectal and lung cancer separately; and for these three cancers combined.
description.edition: adults diagnosed 2000 to 2015 and followed up to 2016
description.title: Index of cancer survival for Clinical Commissioning Groups in England
description.metaDescription: One-year cancer survival for all-cancers combined; for breast, colorectal and lung cancer separately; and for these three cancers combined.
description.headline1: The one-year all-cancer survival index for England increased steadily from 61.2% for patients diagnosed in 2000 to 72.3% in 2015.
description.headline2: The one-year all-cancer survival index increased steadily in most Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) throughout that period; for patients diagnosed in 2015, the all-cancer survival index for CCGs ranged from 67.0% to 77.4%, compared with 49.5% to 66.6% in 2000.
description.headline3: The inequality gap in the cancer survival index between the highest and lowest CCG in England has shrunk since 2000.

description.summary: The value of ordinary shares held in UK incorporated companies listed on the London Stock Exchange by sector of the owner, with a country breakdown for shares owned outside the UK.
description.title: Ownership of UK quoted shares
description.metaDescription: The latest Share Ownership report gives details of beneficial ownership of UK listed companies as at 31 December. This is provided in terms of National Accounts classifications.
description.headline1: At the end of 2016, shares in quoted UK domiciled companies (that is, their country of incorporation is the UK) were worth a total of £2.04 trillion.
description.headline2: The rest of the world sector saw its proportion increase again to set yet another high, holding 53.9% of the value of the UK stock market at the end of 2016.
description.headline3: UK individuals broadly maintained their proportion of UK quoted shares at 12.3% of quoted UK shares, down by 0.1 percentage points from 2014 but still an increase from the historic low of 10.6% in 2012.

description.summary: Live births by age of mother and father, type of registration, median interval between births, number of previous live-born children and National Statistics Socio-economic Classification (NS-SEC).
description.title: Births by parents’ characteristics in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Live births by age of mother and father, type of registration, median interval between births, number of previous live-born children and National Statistics Socio-economic Classification (NS-SEC).
description.headline1: In 2016, 54% of all live births in England and Wales were to mothers aged 30 and over; 68% of fathers were aged 30 and over.
description.headline2: The average age of all fathers increased to 33.3 years in 2016, from 33.2 years in 2015; for mothers the average age rose to 30.4 years, from 30.3 years in 2015.
description.headline3: The average age of first-time mothers increased to 28.8 years in 2016, from 28.6 years in 2015.

description.summary: Information about the demand for goods and services associated with the activity of tourists and the relationship of this demand to the supply of such goods and services within the UK economy.
description.title: The UK Tourism Satellite Account (UK-TSA)
description.metaDescription: The UK Tourism Satellite Account is based on internationally accepted methodology and provides a detailed picture of the economic value of tourism to the UK economy
description.headline1: Tourism direct gross value added (TDGVA) rose 7.0% year-on-year to £64.6 billion in 2015; among the tourism industries, travel agency and other reservation services, accommodation, and food and beverage were the main drivers of the increase.
description.headline2: Preliminary TDGVA figures for 2016 suggest that the tourism industry has continued to grow and is estimated to be worth £66.1 billion – a 2.2% increase on 2015.
description.headline3: Tourism direct employment (TDE) increased 6.9% year-on-year to an estimated 1.5 million, in 2015; growth in tourism jobs within the water transport, rail transport, and food and beverage serving industries underpinned the rise.

description.summary: The changing composition of families over time, comparing the fertility of women of the same age and the number of children they have had.
description.title: Childbearing for women born in different years, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: The changing composition of families over time, comparing the fertility of women of the same age and the number of children they have had.
description.headline1: The average completed family size for women born in 1971, and reaching age 45 years in 2016, was 1.90 children per woman, the lowest level recorded.
description.headline2: The level of childlessness among women born in 1971 (18%) was higher than for women born in 1944 (11%).
description.headline3: The most common number of children for women born in 1971 was two children.

description.summary: A report bringing together statistics to enable more thorough analysis of how domestic abuse is dealt with at the local level within England and Wales.
description.title: Domestic abuse in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: A report bringing together statistics to enable more thorough analysis of how domestic abuse is dealt with at the local level within England and Wales.
description.headline1: An estimated 1.9 million adults aged 16 to 59 years experienced domestic abuse in the last year, according to the year ending March 2017 Crime Survey for England and Wales (1.2 million women, 713,000 men).
description.headline2: The police recorded 1.1 million domestic abuse-related incidents and crimes in the year ending March 2017 and of these, 43% were recorded as domestic abuse-related crimes; domestic abuse-related crimes recorded by the police accounted for 32% of violent crimes.
description.headline3: There were 46 arrests per 100 domestic abuse-related crimes recorded by 39 police forces in the year ending June 2017.

description.summary: More people die in the winter than the summer. We present data by sex, age, region and cause of death.
description.title: Excess winter mortality in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Trends in excess winter mortality in England and Wales in 2016 to 2017 (provisional data) and 2015 to 2016 (final data).
description.headline1: In the 2016 to 2017 winter period, there were an estimated 34,300 excess winter deaths (EWDs) in England and Wales, which represents an excess winter mortality (EWM) index of 20.9%.
description.headline2: Although there has been an increase in EWDs, the number of EWDs does not exceed the peak that was observed in the 2014 to 2015 winter period; however, it was the second highest over the last five winter periods.
description.headline3: Females and the elderly were most affected by excess winter mortality in the 2016 to 2017 winter period.

description.summary: Change in the number of UK businesses broken down by sector of the economy.
description.title: Business demography, UK
description.metaDescription: Births, deaths and survivals of UK enterprises. Active businesses are also shown, so that birth and death rates can be calculated. Figures broken by sector.
description.headline1: The number of UK business births continued to increase from 383,000 to 414,000 between 2015 and 2016, a birth rate of 14.6% compared with a rate of 14.3% in 2015.
description.headline2: The number of UK business deaths also increased from 283,000 to 328,000 between 2015 and 2016, a death rate of 11.6% compared with a rate of 10.5% in 2015.
description.headline3: London was the region with the highest birth rate at 17.5% and the highest death rate at 14%.

description.summary: Annual spending and numbers employed on research and development in the UK broken down by product sector, and civil and defence businesses.
description.title: Business enterprise research and development, UK
description.metaDescription: Annual spending and numbers employed on research and development in the UK broken down by product sector, and civil and defence businesses.
description.headline1: Expenditure on research and development (R&D) performed by UK businesses continued to grow, expanding by £1.2 billion to £22.2 billion in 2016, an increase of 5.6%.
description.headline2: Motor vehicles and parts was the product group that had the largest growth in expenditure on R&D performed by UK businesses, of £562 million (20%).
description.headline3: London had the largest growth in regional business R&D expenditure, increasing by £404 million (21.4%) to £2.3 billion in 2016.

description.summary: Trends in living arrangements including families (with and without dependent children), people living alone and people in shared accommodation, broken down by size and type of household.
description.title: Families and Households
description.metaDescription: Trends in living arrangements including families (with and without dependent children), people living alone and people in shared accommodation, broken down by size and type of household.
description.headline1: In 2017 there were 19.0 million families in the UK, a 15% increase from 16.6 million in 1996.
description.headline2: With 12.9 million families, the married or civil partner couple family remains the most common in 2017, with the cohabiting couple family growing the fastest.
description.headline3: In the UK there were 27.2 million households in 2017, resulting in an average household size of 2.4.

description.summary: Deaths in the UK which are known to be direct consequences of alcohol misuse.
description.title: Alcohol-specific deaths in the UK
description.metaDescription: Deaths caused by diseases known to be related to alcohol consumption, such as cirrhosis of the liver.
description.headline1: In 2016 there were 7,327 alcohol-specific deaths in the UK, an age-standardised rate of 11.7 deaths per 100,000 population.
description.headline2: For the UK, the 2016 alcohol-specific deaths rate continues to remain unchanged since 2013, but is still higher than that observed 15 years ago.
description.headline3: Since 2001 rates of alcohol-specific deaths among males have been an average of 55% higher than those observed among females.

description.summary: National population projections provide an indication of the future size and age structure of the UK and its constituent countries based on a set of assumptions of future fertility, mortality and migration.
description.title: National Population Projections
description.metaDescription: National population projections provide an indication of the future size and age structure of the UK and its constituent countries based on a set of assumptions of future fertility, mortality and migration.
description.headline1: The UK population is projected to increase by 3.6 million (5.5%) over the next 10 years, from an estimated 65.6 million in mid-2016 to 69.2 million in mid-2026.
description.headline2: England is projected to grow more quickly than the other UK nations: 5.9% between mid-2016 and mid-2026, compared with 4.2% for Northern Ireland, 3.2% for Scotland and 3.1% for Wales.
description.headline3: Over the next 10 years, 46% of UK population growth is projected to result from more births than deaths, with 54% resulting from net international migration.

description.summary: Live births by sex, ethnicity and month. Maternities by place of birth and with multiple births. Stillbirths by age of parents and quarter.
description.title: Birth characteristics in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Live births by sex, ethnicity and month. Maternities by place of birth and with multiple births. Stillbirths by age of parents and quarter.

description.summary: An international comparison of labour productivity across the G7 nations, in terms of levels of and growth in GDP per hour and GDP per worker.
description.title: International comparisons of UK productivity (ICP), first estimates
description.metaDescription: An international comparison of labour productivity across the G7 nations, in terms of levels of and growth in GDP per hour and GDP per worker.
description.headline1: Output per hour worked in the UK was 15.1% below the average for the rest of the G7 advanced economies in 2016; this compares with 15.5% in 2015.
description.headline2: Output per worker in the UK was 15.4% below the average for the rest of the G7 in 2016.
description.headline3: Compared with the rest of the G7, the UK had above average productivity growth in both output per hour and output per worker terms in 2016.

description.summary: Experimental Official Statistics on sexual identity in the UK in 2016 by region, sex, age, marital status, ethnicity and National Statistics Socio-economic Classification.
description.title: Sexual identity, UK
description.metaDescription: Experimental Official Statistics on sexual identity in the UK in 2016 by region, sex, age, marital status, ethnicity and National Statistics Socio-economic Classification.
description.headline1: In 2016, just over 1 million (2.0%) of the UK population aged 16 and over identified themselves as lesbian, gay or bisexual (LGB).
description.headline2: The population aged 16 to 24 were the age group most likely to identify as LGB in 2016 (4.1%).
description.headline3: More males (2.3%) than females (1.6%) identified themselves as LGB in 2016.

description.summary: Average Weekly Earnings (AWE) is the key National Statistics indicator of short-term earnings growth, which provides monthly estimates of the level of Average Weekly Earnings per employee.
description.title: Average Weekly Earnings, bonus payments in Great Britain
description.headline1: In the financial year ending 2017 (April 2016 to March 2017), the combined value of all bonuses paid in Great Britain was a record £46.4 billion, growing by 6.5% on the financial year ending 2016 , surpassing the previous highest amount seen in the previous financial year.
description.headline2: The financial and insurance activities industry paid the highest average bonus per employee, at slightly under £14,770, while the health and social work industry paid the lowest average bonus per employee at close to zero.
description.headline3: Bonuses as a percentage of total pay were 6.2% overall in the financial year ending 2017, a small increase on the previous year, but still below the financial year ending 2008 peak of 7.1%; however, since the financial year ending 2001, bonuses for most industries have grown more in percentage terms than regular pay.

description.summary: How the UK is faring in four domains of social capital: personal relationships, social support networks, civic engagement, and trust and cooperative norms.
description.title: Social capital in the UK
description.metaDescription: How the UK is faring in four domains of social capital: personal relationships, social support networks, civic engagement, and trust and cooperative norms.
description.headline1: The most recent data show a largely positive picture of social capital in the UK over the longer-term with over half of the indicators showing improvement over a period of 3 years; a majority of indicators showed improvement or no overall change over the shorter-term 1 year assessment.
description.headline2: Most adults in the UK have at least one close friend, rising from 95% in 2011 to 2012 to 97% in 2014 to 2015. However, there has been a fall in the proportion of people saying they have someone to rely on a lot in case of a serious problem; this figure fell from 86% in 2010 to 2011 to 84% in 2013 to 2014.
description.headline3: Over two-thirds of UK adults (68%) report stopping and talking to their neighbours in 2014 to 2015.

description.summary: Small area model-based households in poverty estimates covering middle layer super output areas (MSOAs) in England and Wales.
description.title: Small area model-based households in poverty estimates, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Small area model-based households in poverty estimates covering middle layer super output areas (MSOAs) in England and Wales.
description.headline1: In the financial year ending 2014, over three-quarters of small areas in England and Wales had less than 20% of households in poverty before housing costs (BHC), with an overall range from 4.9% to 53.6%.
description.headline2: In the financial year ending 2014, of all small areas in England and Wales 55% had less than 20% of households in poverty after housing costs (AHC), with an overall range from 6.7% to 63.7%.
description.headline3: The West Midlands region contained the highest proportion (86%) of small areas with a percentage of households in poverty (BHC) greater than the national median, closely followed by Wales (85%).

description.summary: Long-term trends in the number of children (aged 0 to 14) surviving cancer 5 and 10 years after diagnosis.
description.edition: children diagnosed from 1990 to 2014 and followed up to 2015
description.title: Childhood cancer survival in England
description.metaDescription: Data on survival for children (aged 0 to 14 years) diagnosed with cancer in England from 1990 to 2008, followed up to 31 December 2013.
description.headline1: For all childhood cancers combined, the general trend of increasing 5-year survival has continued for children (0 to 14 years) diagnosed between 1990 and 2014. For children diagnosed in 1990, age-standardised 5-year survival was 67.3%, whilst 5-year survival is predicted to be 83.9% for children diagnosed in 2015.
description.headline2: A similar increasing trend has been observed for 10-year survival. For children diagnosed in 1990, age-standardised 10-year survival was 63.7% and 10-year survival is predicted to be 82.4% for children diagnosed in 2015.
description.headline3: The increases in 5-year and 10-year survival have been observed in each of the age groups 0 to 4 years, 5 to 9 years and 10 to 14 years.

description.summary: An experimental measure of regional GVA (the increase in the value of the economy due to the production of goods and services) at 2 geographical levels (region and sub-region).
description.title: Regional gross value added (production approach), UK
description.metaDescription: Current Price GVA estimates and Real GVA as Chained Volume Measures for NUTS1 and NUTS2 (1998-2012).
description.headline1: Real gross value added (GVA) increased in all NUTS1 regions in 2014. The highest annual increase was in London at 5.1%, followed by the East of England at 4.5%.
description.headline2: Wales had the smallest annual increase in real GVA in 2014 of the NUTS1 regions, at 0.4%.
description.headline3: Of the NUTS2 sub-regions, North Eastern Scotland had the largest annual increase in real GVA in 2014, at 6.9%, followed by Cheshire at 5.9%.

description.summary: The primary measure of regional GVA (the increase in the value of the economy due to the production of goods and services) at 3 geographical levels (region, sub-region and local area).
description.title: Regional gross value added (income approach), UK
description.metaDescription: The primary measure of regional GVA (the increase in the value of the economy due to the production of goods and services) at 3 geographical levels (region, sub-region and local area).
description.headline1: In 2015 gross value added (GVA) per head of population increased in all NUTS1 regions. The highest annual growth was in the North West at 3.0% and the lowest annual growth was in the East Midlands at 1.0%.
description.headline2: At the regional level, in 2015 London had the highest GVA per head at £43,629 while Wales had the lowest at £18,002.
description.headline3: The North West was also the fastest growing NUTS1 region in the UK in 2015 when looking at annual growth in total GVA (in millions of pounds). Total GVA in the North West grew by 3.6% in 2015. East Midlands had the lowest rate of growth in total GVA at 1.8% in 2015.

description.summary: An overview of property crime,  based on analyses from the year ending March 2016 Crime Survey for England and Wales and crimes recorded by police.
description.title: Focus on property crime
description.metaDescription: Analyses on property crime from the 2014 to 2015 Crime Survey for England and Wales and crimes recorded by police
description.headline1: The majority of crime results from the illegal acquisition of property; making up around 2 in 3 of all crime (66%) in the Police Recorded Crime (PRC) series and 80% of all incidents estimated by the Crime Survey for England and Wales (CSEW).
description.headline2: The reduction in property crime has been the main driver in falling crime numbers since the mid-1990s. The CSEW indicates that while there have been long-term declines across most types of property crime, the falls have been most pronounced in vehicle-related thefts (which include attempted thefts as well as actual thefts from and of vehicles), domestic burglary and criminal damage.
description.headline3: Some commentators have suggested that crime has not actually fallen; but rather changed its nature and moved into offence categories not well covered by the official statistics, such as fraud and computer misuse. However, new Experimental Statistics from the CSEW on fraud and computer misuse offences show a substantial volume of crimes (5.8 million) were experienced by the population resident in households in the last 12 months but should be seen in the context of a fall of 10.2 million incidents of property crime since its peak in 1995.

description.summary: Bulletin presents statistics on the number of employee jobs with pay less than the National Minimum Wage or the new National Living Wage in the UK
keywords: annual survey of hours and earnings
annual survey of hours and earnings
description.title: Low pay in the UK
description.metaDescription: The lower end of the earnings distribution and estimates for the number of jobs paid below the National Minimum Wage (NMW)
description.headline1: There were 362,000 jobs with pay less than the National Minimum Wage (NMW) or National Living Wage (NLW) held by employees aged 16 and over in April 2016, which constituted 1.3% of UK employee jobs.
description.headline2: There were 178,000 jobs held by full-time employees (0.9% of jobs in this group) with pay less than the NMW or NLW.
description.headline3: For part-time employees, there were 184,000 jobs (2.4% of jobs in this group) with pay less than the NMW or NLW.

description.summary: Estimates of health state life expectancies for the UK, its constituent countries and their sub-national areas using 2011 Census health and disability prevalence data.
description.title: Health expectancies at birth and at age 65 in the UK, based on 2011 Census health and disability prevalence data
description.metaDescription: Estimates of health state life expectancies for the UK, its constituent countries and their sub-national areas using 2011 Census health and disability prevalence data.
description.headline1: In 2010 to 2012, newborn males and females in the UK could expect to live 78.8 years and 82.6 years respectively.
description.headline2: If they experienced the same health status rates as observed between 2010 and 2012, newborn males could expect to live 63.2 years (or 80.3% of their lives) in “Very good or good” health. Females could expect to live 64.6 years (or 78.2% of their lives) in “Very good or good” health.
description.headline3: If surviving to age 65, men and women could expect to live a further 18.3 years and 20.8 years respectively, of which around half would be in “Very good or good” health (9.1 years and 9.6 years respectively).

description.summary: 1-year, 5-year and 10-year net survival for adults in England diagnosed with 1 of 24 common cancers between 2010 and 2014 and followed up to 2015.
description.edition: Patients diagnosed between 2010 and 2014 and followed up to 2015
description.title: Cancer survival in England
description.metaDescription: 1-year, 5-year and 10-year net survival for adults in England diagnosed with 1 of 24 common cancers between 2010 and 2014 and followed up to 2015.
description.headline1: Among the 24 cancers examined here, 1- and 5-year survival was highest for testicular cancer in men and melanoma of the skin in women. Survival for pancreatic cancer was the lowest at 1 and 5 years for men and women
description.headline2: 10-year survival predicted for patients who would be diagnosed in 2015 was highest for melanoma of the skin and lowest for leukaemia in both sexes
description.headline3: 10-year survival predicted for patients who would be diagnosed in 2015 was highest for melanoma of the skin and lowest for leukaemia in both sexes

description.summary: Deaths where Clostridium difficile or MRSA infections were mentioned on the death certificate by sex, age group and whether the death occurred in hospital or elsewhere.
keywords: C. difficile,hospital infections,care home infections,mortality,deaths of older people
description.title: Deaths involving Clostridium difficile or MRSA, Wales
description.metaDescription: Deaths where Clostridium difficile infection was mentioned on the death certificate by sex, age group and whether the death occurred in hospital or elsewhere.
description.headline1: In 2015, there were 108 deaths involving Clostridium difficile (C. difficile) and 22 deaths involving Meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in Wales.
description.headline2: The C. difficile age-standardised death rate in 2015 is not statistically different to the lowest that was recorded in 1999 (34.3 deaths per 1 million persons in 2015).
description.headline3: The age-standardised death rate for MRSA has also dropped since its peak in the mid-2000s, to 7.0 deaths per 1 million persons in 2015.

description.summary: Residential moves between local authorities and regions in England and Wales, as well as moves to or from the rest of the UK (Scotland and Northern Ireland).
description.title: Internal migration, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: From mid-2016 Population Estimates and Internal Migration were combined in one  Statistical Bulletin. Residential moves between local authorities and regions in England and Wales, as well as moves to or from the rest of the UK (Scotland and Northern Ireland).
description.headline1: There were an estimated 2.85 million residents moving between local authorities in England and Wales between July 2014 and June 2015.  This is the same level shown the previous year.
description.headline2: There were 53,200 moves from England and Wales to Northern Ireland and Scotland, compared with 45,600 from Northern Ireland and Scotland to England and Wales. This means there was a net internal migration loss for England and Wales of 7,600 people.
description.headline3: For the total number of internal migration moves the sex ratio is fairly neutral; in the year to June 2015, 1.4 million (48%) of moves were males and 1.5 million (52%) were females.

description.summary: Survival for people diagnosed by cancer type, split by stage at diagnosis. Data based on people diagnosed in England in 2012, 2013 and 2014. Produced in collaboration with Public Health England (PHE).
description.edition: Adults diagnosed 2012, 2013 and 2014 and followed up to 2015
description.title: Cancer survival by stage at diagnosis for England (experimental statistics)
description.metaDescription: Survival for people diagnosed by cancer type, split by stage at diagnosis. Data based on people diagnosed in England in 2012, 2013 and 2014.
description.headline1: In general, those people diagnosed with early (stage 1 or 2) cancers have a better survival than those diagnosed with late (stage 4) cancer
description.headline2: Apart from lung and ovarian cancer, there is a pattern of similar survival at stages 1-3 and a large decrease for those diagnosed at stage 4
description.headline3: Although stage 4 survival is always the worst for any given cancer, the survival at stage 4 varies from 15% (men with lung cancer) to 83% (men with prostate cancer)

description.summary: This release is methodological in nature and explores the feasibility of producing estimates of productivity for the industries that contribute to the tourism sector. Two methods are explored in the release - one based on the Tourism Satellite Account estimates and the other based on the measures of labour productivity produced by ONS.
description.title: The productivity of tourism industries
description.metaDescription: This release is methodological in nature and explores the feasibility of producing estimates of productivity for the industries that contribute to the tourism sector.
description.headline1: Productivity measures based on the UK Tourism Satellite Account show that tourism productivity growth was higher than non tourism productivity growth between 2008 and 2013
description.headline2: Labour productivity measures based on jobs and hours worked for the accommodation industry show a rise in productivity in 2014 and 2015
description.headline3: The labour productivity of sports activities peaks in quarter 3, 2012 which coincides with the Olympics.

description.summary: Quality of care delivered in the last 3 months of life for adults who died in England.
description.title: National Survey of Bereaved People (VOICES)
description.metaDescription: Quality of care delivered in the last 3 months of life for adults who died in England.
description.headline1: 3 out of 4 bereaved people (75%) rate the overall quality of end of life care for their relative as outstanding, excellent or good; 1 out of 10 (10%) rated care as poor.
description.headline2: Overall quality of care for females was rated significantly higher than males with 44% of respondents rating the care as outstanding or excellent compared with 39% for males.
description.headline3: 7 out of 10 people (69%) rated hospital care as outstanding, excellent or good which is significantly lower compared with care homes (82%), hospice care (79%) or care at home (79%).

description.summary: Impact of the implementation of IRIS cause of death coding software on stillbirths and neonatal deaths
description.title: Impact of the implementation of IRIS software for ICD-10 cause of death coding on stillbirth and neonatal death statistics
description.metaDescription: Impact of the implementation of IRIS cause of death coding software on stillbirths and neonatal deaths

description.title: The effects of taxes and benefits on income inequality
description.metaDescription: The redistribution effects on households of direct and indirect taxation and benefits received in cash or kind analysed by household type, and the changing levels of income inequality over time.

description.summary: Healthy life expectancy (HLE) for males and females at birth and age 65 by English regions, upper tier local authorities and national deciles of area deprivation.
description.title: Healthy life expectancy at birth and age 65 by upper tier local authority and area deprivation
description.metaDescription: 2012 to 2014 estimates of healthy life expectancy (HLE) for males and females at birth and age 65 by English regions, upper tier local authorities (UTLAs) and national deciles of area deprivation.
description.headline1: In 2012 to 2014, males at birth in England could expect to spend a higher proportion (79.7%) of their remaining lives in “Good” health, compared with females (76.9%).
description.headline2: London had the largest inequality in healthy life expectancy (HLE) at birth between upper tier local authorities (UTLAs) for males and females at 13.6 years and 17.6 years respectively.
description.headline3: At birth, males in Wokingham could expect to live 15.5 years longer in “Good” health than males in Blackpool (70.5 years compared with 55.0 years).

description.summary: 2012 to 2014 estimates of disability-free life expectancy for males and females in upper tier local authorities, England at birth and at age 65.
description.title: Disability-Free Life Expectancy by Upper Tier Local Authority
description.metaDescription: 2012 to 2014 estimates of disability-free life expectancy for males and females in upper tier local authorities, England at birth and at age 65.
description.headline1: Males at birth could expect to spend a greater proportion (79.5%) of their lives free from disability compared with females (76.0%)
description.headline2: Males and females living in the South East, South West and East of England could expect to spend more years disability-free compared with those living in other regions
description.headline3: The inequality in disability-free life expectancy (DFLE) at birth across upper tier local authorities was wider for females (19.4 years) than males (16.8 years)

description.summary: The full set of UK government finance statistics supplied under the Maastricht Treaty, including details of the components of government debt and deficit and supplemantary data.
description.title: EU Government Deficit and Debt Return including Maastricht Supplementary Data Tables
description.metaDescription: UK general government deficit and gross debt figures expressed as proportion of GDP as well as Â£s, with supporting information and commentary
description.headline1: General government deficit (net borrowing) was £91.9 billion in the financial year ending March 2015 (5.0% of Gross Domestic Product (GDP)), a decrease of £12.2 billion compared with the financial year ending March 2014
description.headline2: General government gross debt was £1,601.3 billion at the end of the financial year ending March 2015 (87.5% of GDP), an increase of £79.9 billion compared with the end of the financial year ending March 2014
description.headline3: This release is fully consistent with the latest data transmission on UK government deficit (or net borrowing) and debt that the UK and other European Union (EU) member states are required to report quarterly to the European Commission

description.summary: Analysis from the Occupational Pension Schemes Survey (OPSS) on active members of occupational pension schemes, previously presented in Pension Trends Chapter 6 and Chapter 8.
description.edition: employer contribution rates and characteristics by pension benefit structure, 2014
description.title: Pensions short stories, Active members of occupational pensions
description.metaDescription: Analysis from the Occupational Pension Schemes Survey (OPSS) on active members of occupational pension schemes, previously presented in Pension Trends Chapter 6 and Chapter 8.
description.headline1: In 2014, there were 10.2 million active members of occupational pension schemes in the UK, of which 5.4 million were in the public sector and 4.9 million in the private sector.
description.headline2: The private sector has seen an increase in active members from 2011 (2.9 million) to 2014 (4.9 million). Automatic enrolment is likely to have contributed to this increase
description.headline3: In 2014, 53% of total active membership was in the public sector and 47% in the private sector. In 2011, these figures were 65% and 35%, respectively. Automatic enrolment is thought to be the explanation for the changing proportions.

description.summary: Estimates of the economic value of tourism within UK regions, sub-regions and local areas.
description.edition: A spatial classification of areas in England and Wales to show the importance of tourism, at county and unitary authority level, 2011 to 2013
description.title: Sub-National Tourism
description.metaDescription: Estimates of the economic value of tourism within UK regions, sub-regions and local areas.
description.headline1: Analysis on variables in the Atlas of Tourism produced 5 distinct groupings of counties and unitary authorities based upon similarities in their tourism characteristics
description.headline2: Two groups, comprising of 31 geographical areas, have been classified as areas where tourism visits for holiday purposes are important, referred to as ‘holiday hotspots’
description.headline3: Key characteristics of ‘holiday hotspots’ are: higher proportions of jobs in accommodation for visitors, higher percentages of main jobs in tourism and tourism enterprises and higher percentages of inbound trips for a holiday purpose

description.summary: Absolute difference of years spent in favourable health states between the least and most deprived areas, based on the Slope Index of Inequality.
description.title: Inequality in Health and Life Expectancies within Upper Tier Local Authorities
description.metaDescription: Absolute difference of years spent in favourable health states between the least and most deprived areas, based on the Slope Index of Inequality.
description.headline1: In 2009 to 2013, life expectancy at birth in England for males was 79.1 years, but the level of inequality in life expectancy between males living in the most and least deprived parts of England was 7.9 years. Life expectancy for females was 83.0 years. This was 4 years higher than for males, but despite that the level of inequality in female life expectancy between the most and least deprived was 2 years less than for males (5.9 years)
description.headline2: The number of years an individual could expect to live in good health (healthy life expectancy) in 2009 to 2013 was 63.5 years for males and 64.8 years for females. The level of inequality between those living in the most and least deprived parts of England was 16.7 years for males and 16.8 years for females, much greater than the inequality in life expectancy. Inequality in disability-free life expectancy (years of life spent free from disability) was slightly lower than inequality in healthy life expectancy for both males and females (14.5 and 13.6 years, respectively)
description.headline3: In the ten years between 1999 to 2003 and 2009 to 2013, there was little change in the level of inequality in England between the most and least deprived for both life expectancy and disability-free life expectancy among males and females. Data are not available to measure the change in inequality in healthy life expectancy on a comparable basis over this time period

description.summary: Trends for England and Wales (national, regional and local areas) in the average number of years people will live beyond their current age measured by "period life expectancy".
description.title: Life Expectancy at Birth and at Age 65 by Local Areas in England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Trends for England and Wales (national, regional and local areas) in the average number of years people will live beyond their current age measured by "period life expectancy".
description.headline1: In 2012 to 2014, life expectancy for newborn baby boys was highest in Kensington and Chelsea (83.3 years) and lowest in Blackpool (74.7 years). For newborn baby girls, life expectancy was highest in Chiltern (86.7 years) and lowest in Middlesbrough (79.8 years)
description.headline2: When this series first began (1991 to 1993), East Dorset had the highest male and female life expectancy at birth. Two decades later, baby boys in Blackpool and girls in Middlesbrough can still expect lower life expectancy. In contrast, baby girls in Chiltern, and boys in Kensington and Chelsea, can expect to live 4 to 5 years longer
description.headline3: The inequality between the local areas with the highest and lowest newborn life expectancy has increased despite improvements across local areas over the last 2 decades

description.summary: Estimates of life expectancy by personal socioecnomic position using the national statistics socio-economic classification based on occupation.
description.title: Trend in life expectancy at birth and at age 65 by socio-economic position based on the National Statistics Socio-economic Classification, England and Wales
description.metaDescription: Estimates of life expectancy by personal socioecnomic position using the national statistics socio-economic classification based on occupation.
description.headline1: The Slope Index of Inequality shows the gap in life expectancy at birth for males widened overall during the past 30 years from 5.6 years to 6.7 years; however since 1997 to 2001, when it stood at 7.5 years, the gap has narrowed
description.headline2: The Slope Index of Inequality in life expectancy at birth for females widened from 3.8 years to 5.3 years and it was widest in 2007 to 2011
description.headline3: The improvement in male life expectancy at birth between 1982 to 1986 and 2007 to 2011 ranged from 7.1 years for the Intermediate class to 5.8 years for the Routine class; the Higher Managerial and Professional class gained 6.8 years

description.summary: Death rates of pre-term, full-term and post-term babies and various factors that may influence their survival.
description.title: Pregnancy and ethnic factors influencing births and infant mortality
description.metaDescription: Death rates of pre-term, full-term and post-term babies and various factors that may influence their survival.
description.headline1: Babies born in 2013 had an infant mortality rate of 3.8 deaths per 1,000 live births, compared to 3.9 deaths per 1,000 live births for babies born in 2012
description.headline2: Term babies had a significantly lower infant mortality rate (1.4 deaths per 1,000 live births) and pre-term babies had a significantly higher rate (21.1 deaths per 1,000 live births) compared to the overall rate
description.headline3: Pakistani, Black Caribbean and Black African babies (6.7, 6.6 and 6.3 deaths per 1,000 live births respectively) had the highest infant mortality rates

description.summary: Sexual identity, smoking prevalence and perceived general health using data from the Integrated Household Survey.
description.title: Integrated Household Survey (Experimental statistics)
description.metaDescription: Sexual identity, smoking prevalence and perceived general health using data from the Integrated Household Survey.
description.headline1: In 2014, 1.6% of adults in the UK identified their sexual identity as lesbian, gay or bisexual
description.headline2: The likelihood of an adult identifying as lesbian, gay or bisexual decreased with age. Around 2.6% of adults aged 16 to 24 years identified themselves as lesbian, gay or bisexual. This decreased to 0.6% of adults aged 65 and over
description.headline3: Around 0.5% of adults identified themselves as bisexual, with women (0.7%) being twice as likely as men to do so (0.3%)

description.summary: The value of UK exports and imports of goods grouped by industry. Goods are attributed to the industry of which they are the principal products.
description.title: UK Trade in Goods by Classification of Product by Activity CPA(08)
description.metaDescription: The value of UK exports and imports of goods grouped by industry. Goods are attributed to the industry of which they are the principal products.
description.headline1: This publication presents a quarterly analysis of UK exports and imports of goods grouped according to the activity of which those goods are principal products. Data are presented according to the classes of the 2008 Classification of Product by Activity (CPA(08)).
description.headline2: All data are shown on a seasonally adjusted, balance of payments basis at current prices, which provides a comprehensive set of CPA (08) trade in goods figures fully compatible with our balance of payments and national accounts outputs.
description.headline3: The Quarter 2 April to June 2015 issue of UK trade in goods by CPA is consistent with the figures published in the UK trade, July 2015 release of 9 September 2015.

description.summary: Deaths where Meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) was mentioned on the death certificate by sex, age group and whether the death occured in hospital or elsewhere.
description.title: Deaths involving MRSA in Wales
description.metaDescription: Deaths where Meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) was mentioned on the death certificate by sex, age group and whether the death occured in hospital or elsewhere.
description.headline1: There were 25 death certificates mentioning Meticillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) in 2014
description.headline2: In 2014, approximately 1 in 6 death certificates (4 out of 25) mentioning MRSA also identified it as the underlying cause of death
description.headline3: The age-specific MRSA death rates increased with age and tended to be higher for males than females

description.summary: Graduated life tables which give statistics on national life expectancy for England and Wales. Published once every ten years.
description.title: English Life Tables No.17
description.metaDescription: Graduated life tables which give statistics on national life expectancy for England and Wales. Published once every ten years.
description.headline1: Over the last 100 years life expectancy at birth has increased by nearly 3 years per decade
description.headline2: For males, life expectancy at birth increased from 51 years in 1910-1912 to 79 years in 2010-12, while for females it increased from 55 to 83 years

description.title: Pensions short stories
description.metaDescription: Median contribution rates are provided by sector and by variables such as employee age, employer size, annual earnings bands and pension scheme type.
description.headline1: Total contributions are increasing following the introduction of automatic enrolment as there has been a large increase in the number of people that are contributing, but median contribution rates are lower. Median contribution rates are expected to increase as the planned implementation of higher minimum contribution rates proceeds
description.headline2: In the private sector, the number of employees who make contributions at rates above the automatic enrolment minimum contribution rates has remained stable. However, there has been a large increase in the number contributing at rates corresponding to the automatic enrolment current minimum contribution rate, reflecting increased participation in workplace pensions
description.headline3: Private sector employee median contribution rates fell between 2013 and 2014, particularly in the 22 to 29 age band (3% in 2013; 1% in 2014). The fall in the 22 to 29 age band is likely to be because there was a large increase in membership following automatic enrolment, with new members often starting at the minimum contribution level
